definitions.definition: the action or fact of abasing or being abased; humiliation or degradation.
embarrassed, disconcerted, or ashamed.
definitions.example: Harriet looked slightly abashed

origin: Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French abaiss- ; compare with Old French esbaiss-, lengthened stem of esbair, from es- ‘utterly’ + bair ‘astound’.

definitions.definition: make (someone) feel embarrassed, disconcerted, or ashamed.
definitions.example: if anything was officially done or said to him, it did not abash him

origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘rejected’): from Latin abjectus, past participle of abicere ‘reject’, from ab- ‘away’ + jacere ‘to throw’.

definitions.definition: (of something bad) experienced or present to the maximum degree.
definitions.example: his letter plunged her into abject misery

definitions.definition: (of a person or their behaviour) completely without pride or dignity; self-abasing.
definitions.example: an abject apology

origin: late Middle English: from Latin abjurare, from ab- ‘away’ + jurare ‘swear’.

definitions.definition: solemnly renounce (a belief, cause, or claim).
definitions.example: MPs were urged to abjure their Jacobite allegiance

origin: early 16th century: from Latin abrogat- ‘repealed’, from the verb abrogare, from ab- ‘away, from’ + rogare ‘propose a law’.

definitions.definition: repeal or do away with (a law, right, or formal agreement).
definitions.example: a proposal to abrogate temporarily the right to strike

definitions.definition: evade (a responsibility or duty).
definitions.example: we believe the board is abrogating its responsibilities to its shareholders

origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘hide, conceal oneself’): from Latin abscondere ‘hide’, from ab- ‘away, from’ + condere ‘stow’.

definitions.definition: leave hurriedly and secretly, typically to escape from custody or avoid arrest.
definitions.example: the barman absconded with a week's takings
synonyms: show a clean pair of heels

origin: early 17th century: from Latin abstemius, (from ab- ‘from’ + a word related to temetum ‘alcoholic drink’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: indulging only very moderately in something, especially food and drink.
definitions.example: ‘We only had a bottle.’ ‘Very abstemious of you.’

definitions.definition: the action or fact of abasing or being abased; humiliation or degradation.
embarrassed, disconcerted, or ashamed.
definitions.example: Harriet looked slightly abashed

origin: Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French abaiss- ; compare with Old French esbaiss-, lengthened stem of esbair, from es- ‘utterly’ + bair ‘astound’.

definitions.definition: make (someone) feel embarrassed, disconcerted, or ashamed.
definitions.example: if anything was officially done or said to him, it did not abash him

origin: late Middle English: from Latin abjurare, from ab- ‘away’ + jurare ‘swear’.

definitions.definition: solemnly renounce (a belief, cause, or claim).
definitions.example: MPs were urged to abjure their Jacobite allegiance

origin: mid 19th century: from French acquisitif, -ive, from late Latin acquisitivus . from Latin acquisit- ‘acquired’, from the verb acquirere (see acquire).

definitions.definition: excessively interested in acquiring money or material things.
definitions.example: we live in a competitive and acquisitive society

origin: early 17th century (in the sense ‘bitter, pungent’): from acrimony + -ous.

definitions.definition: (typically of speech or discussion) angry and bitter.
definitions.example: an acrimonious dispute about wages

origin: late Middle English: from Latin adducere, from ad- ‘towards’ + ducere ‘to lead’.

definitions.definition: cite as evidence.
definitions.example: a number of factors are adduced to explain the situation

origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘put a person on oath’): from Latin adjurare, from ad- ‘to’ + jurare ‘swear’ (from jus, jur- ‘oath’).

definitions.definition: urge or request (someone) solemnly or earnestly to do something.
definitions.example: I adjure you to tell me the truth

origin: mid 16th century: from Latin affectatio(n- ), from the verb affectare (see affect2).

definitions.definition: behaviour, speech, or writing that is pretentious and designed to impress.
definitions.example: the affectation of a man who measures every word for effect

origin: Old English ālecgan  ‘lay down or aside’.

definitions.definition: diminish or put at rest (fear, suspicion, or worry).
definitions.example: the report attempted to educate the public and allay fears

origin: mid 16th century: from a-2 (expressing direction) + luff. The term was originally an adverb in nautical use, meaning ‘away and to windward!’, i.e. with the ship's head kept close to the wind away from a lee shore etc. towards which it might drift. From this arose the sense ‘at a distance’.

definitions.definition: not friendly or forthcoming; cool and distant.
definitions.example: they were courteous but faintly aloof

definitions.definition: (of a drug) acting to relieve pain.
an analgesic drug.

origin: mid 17th century: from medieval Latin asceticus or Greek askētikos, from askētēs ‘monk’, from askein ‘to exercise’.

definitions.definition: characterized by severe self-discipline and abstention from all forms of indulgence, typically for religious reasons.
definitions.example: an ascetic life of prayer, fasting, and manual labour

definitions.definition: a person who follows an ascetic life.

origin: late 15th century: from Latin asininus, from asinus ‘ass’.

definitions.definition: extremely stupid or foolish.
definitions.example: Lydia ignored his asinine remark

origin: mid 18th century (as a noun): from Latin aspirant- ‘aspiring’, from the verb aspirare (see aspire).

definitions.definition: having ambitions to achieve something, typically to follow a particular career.
definitions.example: an aspirant politician

definitions.definition: a person who has ambitions to achieve something.
definitions.example: an aspirant to the throne

origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘declare or confirm to be true’): from Old French averer, based on Latin ad ‘to’ (implying ‘cause to be’) + verus ‘true’.

definitions.definition: state or assert to be the case.
definitions.example: he averred that he was innocent of the allegations

origin: late 15th century: from obsolete bash  ‘make or become abashed’ (from abash) + -ful.

definitions.definition: reluctant to draw attention to oneself; shy.
definitions.example: everything you need to know but have been too bashful to ask

definitions.definition: (of clothing) looking good on someone.
definitions.example: what a becoming dress!

origin: Old English becuman  ‘come to a place, come (to be or do something)’ (see be-, come), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch bekomen and German bekommen ‘get, receive’.

definitions.definition: begin to be.
definitions.example: she became angry and sulked all day

definitions.definition: (of clothing) look good on or suit (someone).
definitions.example: mourning regalia became her

origin: late Middle English: early form of Bethlehem, referring to the hospital of St Mary of Bethlehem in London, used as an institution for the insane.

definitions.definition: a scene of uproar and confusion.
definitions.example: there was bedlam in the courtroom

definitions.definition: an institution for the care of mentally ill people.
a receptacle used by a bedridden patient for urine and faeces.

origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘repair’ but originally not implying clumsiness): of unknown origin.

definitions.definition: carry out (a task) badly or carelessly.
definitions.example: he was accused of botching the job

definitions.definition: a bungled task.
definitions.example: I've probably made a botch of things

origin: mid 19th century: from the name of Dr Thomas Bowdler (1754–1825), who published an expurgated edition of Shakespeare in 1818, + -ize.

definitions.definition: remove material that is considered improper or offensive from (a text or account), especially with the result that the text becomes weaker or less effective.
definitions.example: every edition of his letters and diaries has been bowdlerized

origin: early 19th century (originally dialect); perhaps a form of rash1.

definitions.definition: self-assertive in a rude, noisy, or overbearing way.
definitions.example: he was brash, cocky, and arrogant

origin: late 18th century: of unknown origin.

definitions.definition: loose broken rock or ice.
definitions.example: brash ice

definitions.definition: clippings from hedges, shrubs, or other plants.
definitions.example: cutting up the timber and burning the brash

origin: mid 19th century: from French, from obsolete à bric et à brac ‘at random’.

definitions.definition: miscellaneous objects and ornaments of little value.
definitions.example: then came donations of bric-a-brac

origin: Old English brīdel (noun), brīdlian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch breidel (noun). bridle (sense 2 of the verb) use is from the action of a horse when reined in.

definitions.definition: the headgear used to control a horse, consisting of buckled straps to which a bit and reins are attached.
definitions.example: grooms came at once to take the bridles

definitions.definition: put a bridle on (a horse).
definitions.example: five horses, saddled and bridled, were tied by the reins to branches of trees

definitions.definition: show one's resentment or anger, especially by throwing up one's head and drawing in one's chin.
definitions.example: she bridled at his tone

origin: mid 18th century: from Italian.

definitions.definition: vigour or vivacity of style or performance.
definitions.example: she told her story with some brio

origin: Middle English: from Old English byrst (of Germanic origin, related to German Borste ) + -le1.

definitions.definition: a short, stiff hair on an animal's skin or a man's face.
(of hair or fur) stand upright away from the skin, typically as a sign of anger or fear.
definitions.example: the hair on the back of his neck bristled

definitions.definition: be covered with or abundant in.
definitions.example: the roof bristled with antennae

origin: mid 17th century (originally denoting European hunters in the Caribbean): from French boucanier, from boucan ‘a frame on which to cook or cure meat’, from Tupi mukem .

definitions.definition: a pirate, originally one operating in the Caribbean.
definitions.example: the marauding buccaneers who used to terrorize the Mediterranean coasts

origin: early 16th century (as a noun): via Latin from Greek boukolikos, from boukolos ‘herdsman’, from bous ‘ox’.

definitions.definition: relating to the pleasant aspects of the countryside and country life.
definitions.example: the church is lovely for its bucolic setting

definitions.definition: a pastoral poem.

origin: mid 16th century: of unknown origin; compare with bumble.

definitions.definition: carry out (a task) clumsily or incompetently.
definitions.example: he bungled his first attempt to manage a group of professional players

definitions.definition: a task carried out in a clumsy or incompetent way.

origin: Middle English: from Old French bourgeonner ‘put out buds’, from borjon ‘bud’, based on late Latin burra ‘wool’.

definitions.definition: begin to grow or increase rapidly; flourish.
definitions.example: the city's suburbs have burgeoned, sprawling out from the centre

definitions.definition: a bud or young shoot.
a meddling or prying person.
definitions.example: others considered him an interfering busybody

origin: mid 17th century: from French cacophonie, from Greek kakophōnia, from kakophōnos ‘ill-sounding’, from kakos ‘bad’ + phōnē ‘sound’.

definitions.definition: a harsh discordant mixture of sounds.
definitions.example: a cacophony of deafening alarm bells

definitions.definition: dishonourable, especially towards a woman (typically used of a man or his behaviour).
definitions.example: an impoverished charmer with caddish tendencies

origin: mid 17th century: from French cajoler .

definitions.definition: persuade (someone) to do something by sustained coaxing or flattery.
definitions.example: he hoped to cajole her into selling the house

origin: late Middle English: from Latin calumnia .

definitions.definition: the making of false and defamatory statements about someone in order to damage their reputation; slander.
definitions.example: a bitter struggle marked by calumny and litigation

definitions.definition: slander (someone).

origin: mid 19th century: from French, literally ‘duck’, also ‘hoax’, from Old French caner ‘to quack’.

definitions.definition: an unfounded rumour or story.
definitions.example: the old canard that LA is a cultural wasteland

definitions.definition: a small winglike projection attached to an aircraft forward of the main wing to provide extra stability or control, sometimes replacing the tail.

origin: late 16th century (originally Scots): from can1 (in the obsolete sense ‘know’) + -y1.

definitions.definition: having or showing shrewdness and good judgement, especially in money or business matters.
definitions.example: canny investors will switch banks if they think they are getting a raw deal

definitions.definition: pleasant; nice.
definitions.example: she's a canny lass

origin: late Middle English: from medieval Latin canopeum ‘ceremonial canopy’, alteration of Latin conopeum ‘mosquito net over a bed’, from Greek kōnōpeion ‘couch with mosquito curtains’, from kōnōps ‘mosquito’.

definitions.definition: an ornamental cloth covering hung or held up over something, especially a throne or bed.
definitions.example: a romantic four-poster bed complete with drapes and a canopy

definitions.definition: the uppermost branches of the trees in a forest, forming a more or less continuous layer of foliage.
definitions.example: woolly monkeys spend hours every day sitting high in the canopy

definitions.definition: cover or provide with a canopy.
definitions.example: the river was canopied by overhanging trees

origin: early 16th century: probably from Latin cantare ‘to sing’ (see chant). The early meaning was ‘musical sound, singing’; in the mid 17th century this gave rise to the senses ‘whining manner of speaking’ and ‘form of words repeated mechanically in such a manner’ (for example a beggar's plea), hence ‘jargon’ (of beggars and other such groups).

definitions.definition: hypocritical and sanctimonious talk, typically of a moral, religious, or political nature.
definitions.example: he had no time for the cant of the priests about sin

definitions.definition: language specific to a particular group or profession and regarded with disparagement.
definitions.example: thieves' cant

definitions.definition: talk hypocritically and sanctimoniously about something.
definitions.example: if they'd stop canting about ‘honest work’ they might get somewhere

origin: Middle English (denoting an edge or brink): from Middle Low German kant, kante, Middle Dutch cant ‘point, side, edge’, based on a Romance word related to medieval Latin cantus ‘corner, side’.

definitions.definition: have or cause to have a slanting or oblique position; tilt.
definitions.example: he canted his head to look at the screen

definitions.definition: a slope or tilt.
definitions.example: the outward cant of the curving walls

definitions.definition: a wedge-shaped block of wood, especially one remaining after the better-quality pieces have been cut off.
definitions.example: a squared-off cant remains, containing the knottiest wood

definitions.definition: Canticles (in biblical references).

origin: mid 18th century: of unknown origin; perhaps a blend of Anglo-Irish cant  ‘auction’ and rancorous (see rancour).

definitions.definition: bad-tempered, argumentative, and uncooperative.
definitions.example: he can be a cantankerous old fossil at times
synonyms: like a bear with a sore head

origin: mid 17th century: from French, from Italian (see capriccio).

definitions.definition: a sudden and unaccountable change of mood or behaviour.
definitions.example: the caprices of the electorate

definitions.definition: another term for capriccio.
definitions.example: the caprice was divided into a theme and eleven variations

origin: early 17th century: from French capricieux, from Italian (see capriccioso).

definitions.definition: given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behaviour.
definitions.example: it's terrible to feel our livelihood hinges on a capricious boss

origin: early 17th century: from Latin castigare ‘reprove’, from castus ‘pure, chaste’.

definitions.definition: reprimand (someone) severely.
definitions.example: he was castigated for not setting a good example

definitions.definition: in a way that is unambiguously explicit and direct.
definitions.example: the rules state categorically, 'No Violence'

origin: late Middle English: via Latin from Greek kaustikos, from kaustos ‘combustible’, from kaiein ‘to burn’.

definitions.definition: able to burn or corrode organic tissue by chemical action.
definitions.example: a caustic cleaner

definitions.definition: sarcastic in a scathing and bitter way.
definitions.example: the players were making caustic comments about the refereeing

definitions.definition: formed by the intersection of reflected or refracted parallel rays from a curved surface.
a caustic substance.
a caustic surface or curve.

origin: late Middle English: via Latin from Greek kautērion ‘branding iron’ (see cauterize).

definitions.definition: an instrument or a caustic substance used for cauterizing.

origin: mid 16th century: from French, from Italian cavaliere, based on Latin caballus ‘horse’. Compare with caballero and chevalier.

definitions.definition: a supporter of King Charles I in the English Civil War.
a small spaniel of a breed with a long snout.
showing a lack of proper concern; offhand.
definitions.example: Anne was irritated by his cavalier attitude

origin: late 15th century: from Old French celerite, from Latin celeritas, from celer ‘swift’.

definitions.definition: swiftness of movement.

origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘judicial sentence’): from Old French censurer (verb), censure (noun), from Latin censura ‘judgement, assessment’, from censere ‘assess’.

definitions.definition: express severe disapproval of (someone or something), especially in a formal statement.
definitions.example: the company was heavily censured by inspectors from the Department of Trade

definitions.definition: the formal expression of severe disapproval.
definitions.example: two MPs were singled out for censure

origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘make warm’): from Old French chaufer ‘make hot’, based on Latin calefacere, from calere ‘be hot’ + facere ‘make’.

definitions.definition: (with reference to a part of the body) make or become sore by rubbing against something.
definitions.example: the collar chafed his neck

definitions.definition: rub (a part of the body) to restore warmth or sensation.
definitions.example: I chafed her feet and wrapped the blanket round her

definitions.definition: become or make annoyed or impatient because of a restriction or inconvenience.
definitions.example: the bank chafed at the restrictions imposed upon it

definitions.definition: wear or damage caused by rubbing.
definitions.example: to prevent chafe the ropes should lie flat

definitions.definition: a state of annoyance.
definitions.example: into what an unprofitable chafe you have put yourself!

origin: late Middle English: from Old French, from medieval Latin carnale, neuter (used as a noun) of carnalis ‘relating to flesh’ (see carnal).

definitions.definition: short for charnel house.
associated with death.
definitions.example: I gagged on the charnel stench of the place

origin: Middle English: apparently formed irregularly from the obsolete verb chaste (see chasten).

definitions.definition: rebuke or reprimand severely.
definitions.example: he chastised his colleagues for their laziness

origin: late 16th century: from French chicanerie, from chicaner ‘to quibble’ (see chicane).

definitions.definition: the use of deception or subterfuge to achieve one's purpose.
definitions.example: storylines packed with political chicanery

origin: Old English cīdan, of unknown origin.

definitions.definition: scold or rebuke.
definitions.example: she chided him for not replying to her letters

origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘bilious’): from Old French cholerique, via Latin from Greek kholerikos, from kholera (see choler).

definitions.definition: bad-tempered or irritable.
definitions.example: he was a choleric, self-important little man
synonyms: like a bear with a sore head

origin: late 19th century: from Greek khthōn ‘earth’ + -ic.

definitions.definition: relating to or inhabiting the underworld.
definitions.example: a chthonic deity

origin: Old English cierlisc, ceorlisc  (see churl, -ish1).

definitions.definition: rude in a mean-spirited and surly way.
definitions.example: it seems churlish to complain

origin: mid 17th century: from medieval Latin circuitosus, from circuitus ‘a way around’ (see circuit).

definitions.definition: (of a route or journey) longer than the most direct way.
definitions.example: the canal followed a circuitous route

origin: late Middle English: from Latin circumscribere, from circum ‘around’ + scribere ‘write’.

definitions.definition: restrict (something) within limits.
definitions.example: the minister's powers are circumscribed both by tradition and the organization of local government

definitions.definition: draw (a figure) round another, touching it at points but not cutting it.
definitions.example: if a hexagon is circumscribed about a circle the lines joining opposite vertices meet in one point

origin: late Middle English: from Latin circumspectus, from circumspicere ‘look around’, from circum ‘around, about’ + specere ‘look’.

definitions.definition: wary and unwilling to take risks.
definitions.example: the officials were very circumspect in their statements

origin: mid 18th century (denoting something designed to elicit applause): from clap1 + trap1.

definitions.definition: absurd or nonsensical talk or ideas.
definitions.example: such sentiments are just pious claptrap

origin: mid 19th century: French, from claquer ‘to clap’. The practice of paying members of an audience for their support originated at the Paris opera.

definitions.definition: a group of sycophantic followers.
definitions.example: she was surrounded by a claque of fawning admirers

definitions.definition: a group of people hired to applaud (or heckle) a performer or public speaker.

origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘place of religious seclusion’): from Old French cloistre, from Latin claustrum, clostrum ‘lock, enclosed place’, from claudere, ‘to close’.

definitions.definition: a covered walk in a convent, monastery, college, or cathedral, typically with a colonnade open to a quadrangle on one side.
definitions.example: the shadowed cloisters of the convent

definitions.definition: seclude or shut up in a convent or monastery.
definitions.example: the monastery was where the Brothers would cloister themselves to meditate

origin: mid 17th century: from Latin cogent- ‘compelling’, from the verb cogere, from co- ‘together’ + agere ‘drive’.

definitions.definition: (of an argument or case) clear, logical, and convincing.
definitions.example: they put forward cogent arguments for British membership

origin: late 18th century: Italian, literally ‘people who know’, from Latin cognoscent- ‘getting to know’, from the verb cognoscere .

definitions.definition: people who are especially well informed about a particular subject.
definitions.example: it's worth taking a tip from the fashion cognoscenti

origin: late Middle English: from Old French coigniage, from coignier ‘to mint’ (see coin).

definitions.definition: coins collectively.
definitions.example: the volume of coinage in circulation

definitions.definition: the invention of a new word or phrase.
definitions.example: the word is of Derrida's own coinage

origin: mid 16th century (in comity (sense 2)): from Latin comitas, from comis ‘courteous’.

definitions.definition: an association of nations for their mutual benefit.
courtesy and considerate behaviour towards others.
definitions.example: a show of public comity in the White House

origin: mid 16th century: from late Latin commensurabilis, from com- ‘together’ + mensurabilis, from mensurare ‘to measure’.

definitions.definition: measurable by the same standard.
definitions.example: the finite is not commensurable with the infinite

definitions.definition: proportionate to.
(of numbers) in a ratio equal to a ratio of integers.

origin: mid 17th century: from late Latin commensuratus, from com- ‘together’ + mensuratus, past participle of mensurare ‘to measure’.

definitions.definition: corresponding in size or degree; in proportion.
definitions.example: salary will be commensurate with age and experience

origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘beneficial, useful’): from French commodieux or medieval Latin commodiosus, based on Latin commodus ‘convenient’.

definitions.definition: roomy and comfortable.
definitions.example: they moved to a more commodious dwelling

definitions.definition: convenient.

origin: late 16th century: from Latin, ‘profit, saving’ (literally ‘what is weighed together’), from compendere, from com- ‘together’ + pendere ‘weigh’.

definitions.definition: a collection of concise but detailed information about a particular subject, especially in a book or other publication.
definitions.example: an invaluable compendium of useful information about language

origin: mid 17th century: French, from complaire ‘acquiesce in order to please’, from Latin complacere ‘to please’.

definitions.definition: willing to please others or to accept what they do or say without protest.
definitions.example: there are too many complaisant doctors signing sick notes

origin: mid 17th century: from medieval Latin compurgatio(n- ), from Latin compurgare, from com- (expressing intensive force) + purgare ‘purify’ (from purus ‘pure’).

definitions.definition: acquittal from a charge or accusation obtained by statements of innocence given by witnesses under oath.

origin: early 17th century: from late Latin concomitant- ‘accompanying’, from concomitari, from con- ‘together with’ + comitari, from Latin comes ‘companion’.

definitions.definition: naturally accompanying or associated.
definitions.example: she loved travel, with all its concomitant worries

definitions.definition: a phenomenon that naturally accompanies or follows something.
definitions.example: he sought promotion without the necessary concomitant of hard work

definitions.definition: filled with sexual desire; lustful.
definitions.example: concupiscent dreams

origin: late Middle English (in the general sense ‘bring together’, also in confer (sense 2)): from Latin conferre, from con- ‘together’ + ferre ‘bring’.

definitions.definition: grant (a title, degree, benefit, or right).
definitions.example: the Minister may have exceeded the powers conferred on him by Parliament

definitions.definition: have discussions; exchange opinions.
definitions.example: the officials were conferring with allies

origin: Middle English: from Old French confondre, from Latin confundere ‘pour together, mix up’. Compare with confuse.

definitions.definition: cause surprise or confusion in (someone), especially by not according with their expectations.
definitions.example: the inflation figure confounded economic analysts
synonyms: cause to be at a stand

definitions.definition: mix up (something) with something else.
definitions.example: he was forever confounding managerialism with idealism

definitions.definition: used to express anger or annoyance.
definitions.example: oh confound it, where is the thing?

definitions.definition: (of a person) pleasing or liked on account of having qualities or interests that are similar to one's own.
definitions.example: his need for some congenial company

origin: early 16th century: from Latin conjugalis, from conjux, conjug- ‘spouse’, from con- ‘together’ + jugum ‘a yoke’.

definitions.definition: relating to marriage or the relationship between a married couple.
definitions.example: conjugal loyalty

origin: mid 17th century: from Latin connubialis, from connubium ‘marriage’, from con- ‘with’ + nubere ‘marry’.

definitions.definition: relating to marriage or the relationship between a married couple; conjugal.
definitions.example: their connubial bed

origin: early 17th century: from French consciencieux, from medieval Latin conscientiosus, from Latin conscientia (see conscience).

definitions.definition: wishing to do one's work or duty well and thoroughly.
definitions.example: a conscientious man, he took his duties very seriously

definitions.definition: relating to a person's conscience.
definitions.example: the individual is denied even the opportunity to break the law on conscientious grounds

origin: early 17th century: from Latin consternatio(n- ), from the verb consternare ‘lay prostrate, terrify’ (see consternate).

definitions.definition: a feeling of anxiety or dismay, typically at something unexpected.
definitions.example: to her consternation her car wouldn't start

origin: late Middle English (as an adjective in the sense ‘completed, accomplished’): from Latin consummat- ‘brought to completion’, from the verb consummare, from con- ‘altogether’ + summa ‘sum total’, feminine of summus ‘highest, supreme’.

definitions.definition: make (a marriage or relationship) complete by having sexual intercourse.
definitions.example: they did not consummate their marriage until months after it took place

definitions.definition: showing great skill and flair.
definitions.example: she dressed with consummate elegance

origin: late Middle English: from Old French, or from late Latin contemptibilis, from Latin contemnere (see contemn).

definitions.definition: deserving contempt; despicable.
definitions.example: a display of contemptible cowardice

origin: late Middle English: from Old French contentieux, from Latin contentiosus, from content- ‘striven’, from the verb contendere .

definitions.definition: causing or likely to cause an argument; controversial.
definitions.example: a contentious issue

origin: mid 16th century: from late Latin contravenire, from Latin contra- ‘against’ + venire ‘come’.

definitions.definition: offend against the prohibition or order of (a law, treaty, or code of conduct).
definitions.example: he contravened the Official Secrets Act

origin: Middle English: from Old French contrit, from Latin contritus, past participle of conterere ‘grind down, wear away’, from con- ‘together’ + terere ‘rub’.

definitions.definition: feeling or expressing remorse at the recognition that one has done wrong.
definitions.example: a contrite tone

origin: Middle English: via Old French from late Latin contritio(n- ), from contrit- ‘ground down’, from the verb conterere (see contrite).

definitions.definition: the state of feeling remorseful and penitent.
definitions.example: to show contrition for his crime he offered to do community service

definitions.definition: the use of skill to create or bring about something, especially with a consequent effect of artificiality.
definitions.example: the requirements of the system, by happy chance and some contrivance, can be summed up in an acronym

definitions.definition: a device, especially in literary or artistic composition, which gives a sense of artificiality.
definitions.example: the often tiresome contrivances of historical fiction

origin: Middle English: from Latin contumacia ‘inflexibility’, from contumax (see contumacious).

definitions.definition: stubborn refusal to obey or comply with authority, especially disobedience to a court order or summons.

origin: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘fit for a feast, festive’): from Latin convivialis, from convivium ‘a feast’, from con- ‘with’ + vivere ‘live’.

definitions.definition: (of an atmosphere or event) friendly, lively, and enjoyable.
definitions.example: a convivial cocktail party

definitions.definition: producing or consisting of convulsions.
definitions.example: a convulsive disease

origin: mid 17th century: French, feminine of coquet ‘wanton’, diminutive of coq ‘male bird, cock’.

definitions.definition: a flirtatious woman.
definitions.example: her transformation from an ice maiden warrior into a winsome coquette

definitions.definition: a crested Central and South American hummingbird, typically with green plumage, a reddish crest, and elongated cheek feathers.

origin: late Middle English (denoting an ornamental braid): from Italian cordone, augmentative of corda, and French cordon, diminutive of corde, both from Latin chorda ‘string, rope’ (see cord). cordon (sense 3 of the noun), the earliest of the current noun senses, dates from the early 18th century.

definitions.definition: a line or circle of police, soldiers, or guards preventing access to or from an area or building.
definitions.example: the crowd was halted in front of the police cordon

definitions.definition: a fruit tree trained to grow as a single stem.
a projecting course of brick or stone on the face of a wall.
prevent access to or from an area or building by surrounding it with police or other guards.
definitions.example: the city centre was cordoned off after fires were discovered in two stores

origin: mid 17th century (as a noun): from cosmopolite + -an.

definitions.definition: including people from many different countries.
definitions.example: immigration transformed the city into a cosmopolitan metropolis

definitions.definition: (of a plant or animal) found all over the world.
a cosmopolitan person.
definitions.example: cosmopolitans who spoke both Spanish and English

definitions.definition: a plant or animal found all over the world.
a cocktail made with Cointreau, lemon vodka, cranberry juice, and lime juice.

origin: Middle English: from Old French contenance ‘bearing, behaviour’, from contenir (see contain). The early sense was ‘bearing, demeanour’, also ‘facial expression’, hence ‘the face’.

definitions.definition: a person's face or facial expression.
definitions.example: his impenetrable eyes and inscrutable countenance give little away

definitions.definition: support or approval.
definitions.example: she was giving her specific countenance to the occasion

definitions.definition: admit as acceptable or possible.
definitions.example: he was reluctant to countenance the use of force

origin: late Middle English: from Old French contrepois from contre ‘against’ + pois from Latin pensum ‘weight’. Compare with poise1. The verb, originally counterpeise, from Old French contrepeser, was altered under the influence of the noun in the 16th century.

definitions.definition: a factor or force that balances or neutralizes another.
definitions.example: the organization sees the power of Brussels as a counterpoise to that of London

definitions.definition: have an opposing and balancing effect on.
definitions.example: they make a delightful couple, his gentle intellectuality counterpoised by her firm practicality

definitions.definition: set against or in opposition to.
definitions.example: his book counterposes the darkness of formal religion to the inner light of personal spirituality

origin: Middle English: from Old French coi, quei, from Latin quietus (see quiet). The original sense was ‘quiet, still’ (especially in behaviour), later ‘modestly retiring’, and hence (of a woman) ‘affecting to be unresponsive to advances’.

definitions.definition: (especially with reference to a woman) making a pretence of shyness or modesty which is intended to be alluring.
definitions.example: she treated him to a coy smile of invitation

definitions.definition: reluctant to give details about something regarded as sensitive.
definitions.example: he is coy about his age

definitions.definition: Company.

origin: Middle English: Latin, ‘I believe’. Compare with creed.

definitions.definition: a statement of the beliefs or aims which guide someone's actions.
definitions.example: he announced his credo in his first editorial

definitions.definition: a tendency to be too ready to believe that something is real or true.
definitions.example: moneylenders prey upon their credulity and inexperience

origin: early 19th century: from crotchet (sense 2) + -y1.

definitions.definition: irritable.
definitions.example: he was tired and crotchety
synonyms: like a bear with a sore head

origin: Middle English: from Old French coillier, based on Latin colligere (see collect1).

definitions.definition: reduce the population of (a wild animal) by selective slaughter.
definitions.example: he sees culling deer as a necessity

definitions.definition: select from a large quantity; obtain from a variety of sources.
definitions.example: anecdotes culled from Greek and Roman history

definitions.definition: a selective slaughter of animals.
definitions.example: fishermen are to campaign for a seal cull

definitions.definition: responsibility for a fault or wrong; blame.
definitions.example: a level of moral culpability

origin: late Middle English: from Old French cupidite or Latin cupiditas, from cupidus ‘desirous’, from cupere ‘to desire’. Compare with covet.

definitions.definition: greed for money or possessions.
definitions.example: new wealth, however tainted by cupidity and egoism, tends to be favourable for the arts

definitions.definition: (especially of an old person) bad-tempered and negative.
definitions.example: a curmudgeonly old man

origin: late 15th century: from obsolete curtal  ‘horse with a docked tail’, from French courtault, from court ‘short’, from Latin curtus . The change in the ending was due to association with tail1 and perhaps also with French tailler ‘to cut’.

definitions.definition: reduce in extent or quantity; impose a restriction on.
definitions.example: civil liberties were further curtailed

definitions.definition: believing that people are motivated purely by self-interest; distrustful of human sincerity or integrity.
definitions.example: he was brutally cynical and hardened to every sob story under the sun

definitions.definition: concerned only with one's own interests and typically disregarding accepted standards in order to achieve them.
definitions.example: a cynical manipulation of public opinion

origin: mid 17th century: related to dialect daddle, doddle  ‘dally’.

definitions.definition: waste time; be slow.
definitions.example: she mustn't dawdle—she had to make the call now

origin: Old English dēore, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch dier ‘beloved’, also to Dutch duur and German teuer ‘expensive’.

definitions.definition: regarded with deep affection.
definitions.example: a dear friend

definitions.definition: expensive.
definitions.example: five pounds—that's a bit dear!

definitions.definition: used as an affectionate or friendly form of address.
definitions.example: don't you worry, dear

definitions.definition: at a high cost.
definitions.example: they buy property cheaply and sell dear

definitions.definition: used in expressions of surprise, dismay, or sympathy.
definitions.example: oh dear, I've upset you

origin: Middle English derthe  (see dear, -th2).

definitions.definition: a scarcity or lack of something.
definitions.example: there is a dearth of evidence

origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘humiliate, belittle’): from de- ‘down’ + the obsolete verb base (compare with abase), expressing the notion ‘bring down completely’.

definitions.definition: reduce (something) in quality or value; degrade.
definitions.example: the love episodes debase the dignity of the drama

definitions.definition: lower the value of (coinage) by reducing the content of precious metal.
definitions.example: the King was forced to debase the coinage

definitions.definition: indulging in or characterized by excessive indulgence in sex, alcohol, or drugs.
definitions.example: a debauched lifestyle

origin: late 16th century: from French débaucher (verb) ‘turn away from one's duty’, from Old French desbaucher, of uncertain ultimate origin.

definitions.definition: destroy or debase the moral purity of; corrupt.
definitions.example: he has debauched the morals of the people and endeavoured to corrupt parliament

definitions.definition: excessive indulgence in sex, alcohol, or drugs.

origin: late Middle English (denoting a voucher issued by a royal household, giving the right to claim payment for goods or services): from Latin debentur ‘are owing’ (from debere ‘owe’), used as the first word of a certificate recording a debt. The current sense dates from the mid 19th century.

definitions.definition: a long-term security yielding a fixed rate of interest, issued by a company and secured against assets.

origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘meek or courteous’): from Old French debonaire, from de bon aire ‘of good disposition’.

definitions.definition: confident, stylish, and charming (typically used of a man).
definitions.example: all the men looked debonair and handsome in white tie and tails

origin: late Middle English: from French déclamer or Latin declamare, from de- (expressing thoroughness) + clamare ‘to shout’.

definitions.definition: utter or deliver words in a rhetorical or impassioned way, as if to an audience.
definitions.example: she declaimed her views

origin: mid 16th century (as a literary term, denoting suitability of style): from Latin, neuter of the adjective decorus ‘seemly’.

definitions.definition: behaviour in keeping with good taste and propriety.
definitions.example: he had acted with the utmost decorum

origin: late Middle English: from Latin decrepitus, from de- ‘down’ + crepitus, past participle of crepare ‘rattle, creak’.

definitions.definition: worn out or ruined because of age or neglect.
definitions.example: a row of decrepit houses

origin: mid 17th century: from French déférence, from déférer ‘refer’ (see defer2).

definitions.definition: polite submission and respect.
definitions.example: he addressed her with the deference due to age

origin: late Middle English (also in the sense ‘overthrow, abase, degrade’): from Latin deject- ‘thrown down’, from the verb deicere, from de- ‘down’ + jacere ‘to throw’.

definitions.definition: make sad or dispirited; depress.
definitions.example: nothing dejects a trader like the interruption of his profits

origin: late Middle English: from Old French, variant of diluve, from Latin diluvium, from diluere ‘wash away’.

definitions.definition: a severe flood.
definitions.example: this may be the worst deluge in living memory

definitions.definition: overwhelm with a flood.
definitions.example: caravans were deluged by the heavy rains

origin: Old English delfan  ‘dig’, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch delven .

definitions.definition: reach inside a receptacle and search for something.
definitions.example: she delved in her pocket

definitions.definition: dig; excavate.
definitions.example: when Adam delved and Eve span, who was then the gentleman?

origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘linger, delay’): from Old French demourer (verb), demeure (noun), based on Latin de- ‘away, completely’ + morari ‘delay’.

definitions.definition: raise objections or show reluctance.
definitions.example: normally she would have accepted the challenge, but she demurred

definitions.definition: the action of objecting to or hesitating over something.
definitions.example: they accepted this ruling without demur

origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘sober, serious, reserved’): perhaps from Old French demoure, past participle of demourer ‘remain’ (see demur); influenced by Old French mur ‘grave’, from Latin maturus ‘ripe or mature’. The sense ‘reserved, shy’ dates from the late 17th century.

definitions.definition: reserved, modest, and shy (typically used of a woman).
definitions.example: a demure young lady

origin: late Middle English deynseyn, via Anglo-Norman French from Old French deinz ‘within’ (from Latin de ‘from’ + intus ‘within’) + -ein (from Latin -aneus ‘-aneous’). The change in the form of the word was due to association with citizen.

definitions.definition: a person, animal, or plant that lives or is found in a particular place.
definitions.example: denizens of field and forest

origin: mid 18th century: French dénouement, from dénouer ‘unknot’.

definitions.definition: the final part of a play, film, or narrative in which the strands of the plot are drawn together and matters are explained or resolved.
definitions.example: the film's denouement was unsatisfying and ambiguous

origin: late Middle English: via Old French from late Latin derisio(n- ), from deridere ‘scoff at’.

definitions.definition: contemptuous ridicule or mockery.
definitions.example: my stories were greeted with derision and disbelief

origin: mid 17th century: from derision, on the pattern of the pair decision, decisive .

definitions.definition: expressing contempt or ridicule.
definitions.example: he gave a harsh, derisive laugh

origin: early 17th century (in the sense ‘derisive’): from late Latin derisorius, from deris- ‘scoffed at’, from the verb deridere (see derision).

definitions.definition: ridiculously small or inadequate.
definitions.example: they were given a derisory pay rise

definitions.definition: another term for derisive.
definitions.example: his derisory gaze swept over her

definitions.definition: the removal of moisture from something.
definitions.example: long periods of drought have led to the desiccation of farming land

origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘deserted, abandoned, empty’): from Latin destitutus, past participle of destituere ‘forsake’, from de- ‘away from’ + statuere ‘to place’.

definitions.definition: extremely poor and lacking the means to provide for oneself.
definitions.example: the charity cares for destitute children
synonyms: without a penny to one's name
as poor as a church mouse

origin: late 16th century (denoting a disquisition): from French, via Latin from Greek diatribē ‘spending of time, discourse’, from dia ‘through’ + tribein ‘rub’.

definitions.definition: a forceful and bitter verbal attack against someone or something.
definitions.example: a diatribe against consumerism

origin: mid 17th century: from Greek didaktikos, from didaskein ‘teach’.

definitions.definition: intended to teach, particularly in having moral instruction as an ulterior motive.
definitions.example: a didactic novel that set out to expose social injustice

definitions.definition: modesty or shyness resulting from a lack of self-confidence.
definitions.example: I say this with some diffidence

origin: early 16th century (in the sense ‘waste, squander’): from Latin dilapidat- ‘demolished, squandered’, from the verb dilapidare, literally ‘scatter as if throwing stones’, from di- ‘apart, abroad’ + lapis, lapid- ‘stone’.

definitions.definition: cause (something) to fall into disrepair or ruin.
definitions.example: a ruined Chappell, built by the Spaniard, and dilapidated by the Dutch

origin: late Middle English (also in the sense ‘squandering, waste’): from late Latin dilapidatio(n- ), from Latin dilapidare ‘demolish, squander’ (see dilapidate).

definitions.definition: the state or process of falling into decay or being in disrepair.
definitions.example: the mill was in a state of dilapidation

origin: late Middle English: from late Latin dilatorius ‘delaying’, from Latin dilator ‘delayer’, from dilat- ‘deferred’, from the verb differre .

definitions.definition: slow to act.
definitions.example: he had been dilatory in appointing a solicitor

definitions.definition: strong disapproval, typically on moral grounds.
definitions.example: she braved her mother's disapprobation and slipped out to enjoy herself

origin: late Middle English: from Old French desavouer .

definitions.definition: deny any responsibility or support for.
definitions.example: the union leaders resisted pressure to disavow picket-line violence

origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘defeat in battle’): from Old French desconfit, past participle of desconfire, based on Latin dis- (expressing reversal) + conficere ‘put together’ (see confection).

definitions.definition: make (someone) feel uneasy or embarrassed.
definitions.example: he was not noticeably discomfited by her tone

origin: early 18th century: from obsolete French discommoder, variant of incommoder (see incommode).

definitions.definition: cause (someone) trouble or inconvenience.
definitions.example: I am sorry to have discommoded you

origin: late 17th century (in the sense ‘upset the progress of’): from obsolete French desconcerter, from des- (expressing reversal) + concerter ‘bring together’.

definitions.definition: disturb the composure of; unsettle.
definitions.example: the abrupt change of subject disconcerted her
synonyms: cause to be at a stand

origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘discernment’): via Old French from Latin discretio(n- ) ‘separation’ (in late Latin ‘discernment’), from discernere (see discern).

definitions.definition: the quality of behaving or speaking in such a way as to avoid causing offence or revealing confidential information.
definitions.example: she knew she could rely on his discretion

definitions.definition: the freedom to decide what should be done in a particular situation.
definitions.example: local authorities should use their discretion in setting the charges

definitions.definition: available for use at the discretion of the user.
definitions.example: there has been an increase in year-end discretionary bonuses

origin: late Middle English: from Latin disparatus ‘separated’, from the verb disparare, from dis- ‘apart’ + parare ‘to prepare’; influenced in sense by Latin dispar ‘unequal’.

definitions.definition: essentially different in kind; not able to be compared.
definitions.example: they inhabit disparate worlds of thought

definitions.definition: things so unlike that there is no basis for comparison.
(of a person or way of life) overindulging in sensual pleasures.
definitions.example: dissipated behaviour

origin: late Middle English: from Latin dissipat- ‘scattered’, from the verb dissipare, from dis- ‘apart, widely’ + supare ‘to throw’.

definitions.definition: (with reference to a feeling or emotion) disappear or cause to disappear.
definitions.example: the concern she'd felt for him had wholly dissipated

definitions.definition: waste or fritter away (money, energy, or resources).
definitions.example: he inherited, but then dissipated, his father's fortune

origin: mid 17th century (in the dialect sense ‘tremble, quiver’): variant of dialect didder ; related to dodder1.

definitions.definition: be indecisive.
definitions.example: I can't bear people who dither

definitions.definition: add white noise to (a digital recording) to reduce distortion of low-amplitude signals.
indecisive behaviour.
definitions.example: after months of dither ministers had still not agreed

definitions.definition: a state of agitation.
definitions.example: all of a dither, he prophesied instant chaos

origin: late 19th century: via German from Latin docent- ‘teaching’, from docere ‘teach’.

definitions.definition: (in certain US and European universities and colleges) a member of the teaching staff immediately below professorial rank.
a person who acts as a guide, typically on a voluntary basis, in a museum, art gallery, or zoo.
moving in a feeble or unsteady way, especially because of old age.
definitions.example: that doddering old fool

origin: early 17th century: variant of obsolete dialect dadder ; related to dither.

definitions.definition: move in a feeble or unsteady way, especially because of old age.
definitions.example: an elderly couple gave us a concerned glance as they doddered past

definitions.definition: expressing sorrow; mournful.
definitions.example: a doleful look

origin: Middle English: variant of dungeon.

definitions.definition: the great tower or innermost keep of a castle.

origin: Middle English: perhaps from an unrecorded Old English word related to German Treber, Träber ‘husks, grains’, and perhaps also to drivel.

definitions.definition: dregs or refuse.

origin: late 15th century (as a noun; originally in dredge-boat ): perhaps related to Middle Dutch dregghe ‘grappling hook’.

definitions.definition: clear the bed of (a harbour, river, or other area of water) by scooping out mud, weeds, and rubbish with a dredge.
definitions.example: the lower stretch of the river had been dredged

definitions.definition: an apparatus for bringing up objects or mud from a river or seabed by scooping or dragging.

origin: late 16th century: from obsolete dredge  ‘sweetmeat, mixture of spices’, from Old French dragie, perhaps via Latin from Greek tragēmata ‘spices’. Compare with dragée.

definitions.definition: sprinkle (food) with a powdered substance such as flour or sugar.
definitions.example: dredge the bananas with sugar and cinnamon

origin: Middle English: probably of Scandinavian origin and related to Swedish drägg (plural).

definitions.definition: the remnants of a liquid left in a container, together with any sediment.
definitions.example: coffee dregs

origin: Old English drōs (in the sense ‘scum on molten metal’); related to Dutch droesem and German Drusen ‘dregs, lees’.

definitions.definition: something regarded as worthless; rubbish.
definitions.example: there are bargains if you have the patience to sift through the dross

definitions.definition: foreign matter, dregs, or mineral waste, in particular scum formed on the surface of molten metal.
definitions.example: alchemists tried to create gold from dross

definitions.definition: deceitful.
definitions.example: a duplicitous philanderer

definitions.definition: (of a charge or plea) containing more than one allegation.

origin: late 16th century: from Dutch ezel ‘ass’. The word ‘horse’ is used in English in a similar way to denote a supporting frame.

definitions.definition: a wooden frame for holding an artist's work while it is being painted or drawn.

origin: late 16th century (in the sense ‘boiling’): from Latin ebullient- ‘boiling up’, from the verb ebullire, from e- (variant of ex- ) ‘out’ + bullire ‘to boil’.

definitions.definition: cheerful and full of energy.
definitions.example: she sounded ebullient and happy

definitions.definition: (of liquid or matter) boiling or agitated as if boiling.
definitions.example: misted and ebullient seas

origin: late 17th century: from Latin effervescent- ‘boiling up’, from the verb effervescere (see effervesce).

definitions.definition: (of a liquid) giving off bubbles; fizzy.
definitions.example: an effervescent mixture of cheap wine, fruit flavours, sugar, and carbon dioxide

definitions.definition: vivacious and enthusiastic.
definitions.example: effervescent young people
synonyms: full of the joys of spring

origin: mid 16th century: from Latin effigies, from effingere ‘to fashion (artistically)’, from ex- ‘out’ + fingere ‘to shape’.

definitions.definition: a sculpture or model of a person.
definitions.example: a tomb effigy of Eleanor of Aquitaine

origin: late 17th century: from French effronterie, based on late Latin effrons, effront- ‘shameless, barefaced’, from ex- ‘out’ + frons ‘forehead’.

definitions.definition: insolent or impertinent behaviour.
definitions.example: one juror had the effrontery to challenge the coroner's decision

definitions.definition: showing or expressing gratitude, pleasure, or approval in an unrestrained or heartfelt manner.
definitions.example: an effusive welcome

definitions.definition: (of igneous rock) poured out when molten and later solidified.

origin: mid 16th century (in egregious (sense 2)): from Latin egregius ‘illustrious’, literally ‘standing out from the flock’, from ex- ‘out’ + grex, greg- ‘flock’. Sense 1 (late 16th century) probably arose as an ironic use.

definitions.definition: outstandingly bad; shocking.
definitions.example: egregious abuses of copyright

definitions.definition: remarkably good.

origin: mid 19th century: from French élan, from élancer ‘to dart’, from é- ‘out’ + lancer ‘to throw’.

definitions.definition: energy, style, and enthusiasm.
definitions.example: they performed with uncommon elan onstage

definitions.definition: something which originates or issues from a source.
definitions.example: she saw the insults as emanations of his own tortured personality

definitions.definition: (in various mystical traditions) a being or force which is a manifestation of God.
definitions.example: they believe that each human soul is an emanation of Godhood

definitions.definition: (of a surface or object) decorated with a design that stands out in relief.
definitions.example: an embossed brass dish

origin: late Middle English: from the Old French base of obsolete French embosser, from em- ‘into’ + boce ‘protuberance’.

definitions.definition: carve, mould, or stamp a design on (a surface or object) so that it stands out in relief.
definitions.example: they used special tools to emboss the leather

origin: mid 17th century: from Greek emetikos, from emein ‘to vomit’.

definitions.definition: (of a substance) causing vomiting.
a medicine or other substance which causes vomiting.

origin: Middle English: from Latin eminentia, from eminere ‘jut, project’.

definitions.definition: fame or acknowledged superiority within a particular sphere.
definitions.example: her eminence in cinematography

definitions.definition: a piece of rising ground.
definitions.example: an eminence commanding the River Emme

origin: early 17th century: from Latin emissarius ‘scout, spy’, from emittere ‘send out’ (see emit).

definitions.definition: a person sent as a diplomatic representative on a special mission.

origin: mid 16th century: Latin, from Greek enkōmion ‘eulogy’, from en- ‘within’ + komos ‘revel’.

definitions.definition: a speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly.

origin: mid 16th century: Latin, from Greek enkōmion ‘eulogy’, from en- ‘within’ + komos ‘revel’.

definitions.definition: a speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly.

origin: early 17th century: from Latin enervat- ‘weakened (by extraction of the sinews)’, from the verb enervare, from e- (variant of ex-) ‘out of’ + nervus ‘sinew’.

definitions.definition: make (someone) feel drained of energy or vitality.
definitions.example: the heat enervated us all

definitions.definition: lacking in energy or vitality.
definitions.example: the enervate slightness of his frail form

origin: late Middle English (formerly also as ingross ): based on en-1, in-2 ‘in’ + late Latin grossus ‘large’. Sense 1 is from Old French en gros, from medieval Latin in grosso ‘wholesale’; sense 2 comes from Anglo-Norman French engrosser, medieval Latin ingrossare, from Old French grosse, medieval Latin grossa ‘large writing’, with reference to clerks writing out documents in large, clear writing.

definitions.definition: absorb all the attention or interest of.
definitions.example: they seemed to be engrossed in conversation

definitions.definition: produce (a legal document, especially a deed or statute) in its final form.
definitions.example: the solicitors will submit a draft conveyance and engross the same after approval
synonyms: print out the final version of

origin: Middle English: from Old French enemi(s)tie, based on Latin inimicus (see enemy).

definitions.definition: a state or feeling of active opposition or hostility.
definitions.example: decades of enmity between the two countries

origin: late 16th century (in the senses ‘fortify’ and ‘shelter within or behind a fortification’; formerly also as insconce ): from en-1, in-2 ‘in’ + sconce2.

definitions.definition: establish or settle (someone) in a comfortable, safe place.
definitions.example: Agnes ensconced herself in their bedroom

origin: late Middle English (denoting a disciple of Epicurus): via medieval Latin from Greek Epikouros ‘Epicurus’.

definitions.definition: a person who takes particular pleasure in fine food and drink.
definitions.example: they see themselves as epicures—delighting in food that is properly prepared

origin: late 16th century: from French épithète, or via Latin from Greek epitheton, neuter of epithetos ‘attributed’, from epitithenai ‘add’, from epi ‘upon’ + tithenai ‘to place’.

definitions.definition: an adjective or phrase expressing a quality or attribute regarded as characteristic of the person or thing mentioned.
definitions.example: old men are often unfairly awarded the epithet ‘dirty’

origin: mid 17th century: from equi- ‘equal’ + the noun poise1, replacing the phrase equal poise .

definitions.definition: balance of forces or interests.
definitions.example: this temporary equipoise of power

definitions.definition: balance or counterbalance (something).
definitions.example: as a piece of language it is as delicately equipoised as any

origin: late 19th century: from German, literally ‘replacement’.

definitions.definition: (of a product) made or used as a substitute, typically an inferior one, for something else.
definitions.example: ersatz coffee

origin: late Middle English: from Old French eschiver, ultimately of Germanic origin and related to German scheuen ‘shun’, also to shy1.

definitions.definition: deliberately avoid using; abstain from.
definitions.example: he appealed to the crowd to eschew violence

origin: Middle English: from Old French espier, ultimately of Germanic origin and related to Dutch spieden and German spähan . Compare with spy.

definitions.definition: catch sight of.
definitions.example: she espied her daughter rounding the corner

origin: early 18th century (in the sense ‘almost imperceptible’): from Latin evanescent- ‘disappearing’, from the verb evanescere (see evanesce).

definitions.definition: soon passing out of sight, memory, or existence; quickly fading or disappearing.
definitions.example: the evanescent Arctic summer

definitions.definition: denoting a field or wave which extends into a region where it cannot propagate and whose amplitude therefore decreases with distance.

origin: late 16th century (in the sense ‘prove by argument or evidence’): from Latin evincere ‘overcome, defeat’ (see evict).

definitions.definition: reveal the presence of (a quality or feeling); indicate.
definitions.example: the news stories evinced the usual mixture of sympathy and satisfaction

definitions.definition: (of a person or their rank or status) at a high or powerful level.
definitions.example: it had taken her years of infighting to reach her present exalted rank

definitions.definition: in a state of extreme happiness.
definitions.example: I felt exalted and newly alive

origin: late Middle English: from Latin exaltare, from ex- ‘out, upward’ + altus ‘high’.

definitions.definition: think or speak very highly of (someone or something).
definitions.example: the party will continue to exalt their hero

definitions.definition: raise to a higher rank or position.
definitions.example: this naturally exalts the peasant above his brethren in the same rank of society

origin: late Middle English: from Latin excoriat- ‘skinned’, from the verb excoriare, from ex- ‘out, from’ + corium ‘skin, hide’.

definitions.definition: damage or remove part of the surface of (the skin).
definitions.example: the discharge is acrid and excoriates the skin of the nose

definitions.definition: criticize (someone) severely.
definitions.example: he excoriated the government for censorship

origin: late 16th century: from late Latin exemplaris, from Latin exemplum ‘sample, imitation’ (see example).

definitions.definition: serving as a desirable model; very good.
definitions.example: exemplary behaviour

definitions.definition: (of a punishment) serving as a warning or deterrent.
definitions.example: exemplary sentencing may discourage the violent minority

origin: late Middle English: from Old French exhorter or Latin exhortari, from ex- ‘thoroughly’ + hortari ‘encourage’.

definitions.definition: strongly encourage or urge (someone) to do something.
definitions.example: I exhorted her to be a good child

origin: late Middle English: from Latin expedient- ‘extricating, putting in order’, from the verb expedire (see expedite).

definitions.definition: (of an action) convenient and practical although possibly improper or immoral.
definitions.example: either side could break the agreement if it were expedient to do so

definitions.definition: a means of attaining an end, especially one that is convenient but possibly improper or immoral.
definitions.example: the current policy is a political expedient

definitions.definition: the act of making amends or reparation for guilt or wrongdoing; atonement.
definitions.example: an act of public expiation

definitions.definition: the process of analysing and developing an idea or principle in detail.
definitions.example: this term is meaningless without further explication and analysis

origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘demand how or why, state a complaint’): from Latin expostulat- ‘demanded’, from the verb expostulare, from ex- ‘out’ + postulare ‘demand’.

definitions.definition: express strong disapproval or disagreement.
definitions.example: he found Fox expostulating with a young man

origin: late 16th century: from medieval Latin expropriat- ‘taken from the owner’, from the verb expropriare, from ex- ‘out, from’ + proprium ‘property’, neuter singular of proprius ‘own’.

definitions.definition: (of the state or an authority) take (property) from its owner for public use or benefit.
definitions.example: their assets were expropriated by the government

origin: early 17th century (in the sense ‘purge of excrement’): from Latin expurgat- ‘thoroughly cleansed’, from the verb expurgare, from ex- ‘out’ + purgare ‘cleanse’.

definitions.definition: remove matter thought to be objectionable or unsuitable from (a text or account).
definitions.example: editors heavily expurgated the novel before its initial publication

origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘able to be publicly seen or reached’): from Latin exstant- ‘being visible or prominent, existing’, from the verb exstare, from ex- ‘out’ + stare ‘to stand’.

definitions.definition: still in existence; surviving.
definitions.example: an extant letter

origin: late Middle English: from Latin extollere, from ex- ‘out, upward’ + tollere ‘raise’.

definitions.definition: praise enthusiastically.
definitions.example: he extolled the virtues of the Russian peoples

origin: late 16th century: from Latin exsultare, frequentative of exsilire ‘leap up’, from ex- ‘out, upward’ + salire ‘to leap’.

definitions.definition: feel or show triumphant elation or jubilation.
definitions.example: exulting in her escape, Lisa closed the door behind her
synonyms: be on top of the world
pat oneself on the back for

origin: late 15th century (in the sense ‘easily accomplished’): from French, or from Latin facilis ‘easy’, from facere ‘do, make’.

definitions.definition: ignoring the true complexities of an issue; superficial.
definitions.example: facile generalizations

definitions.definition: (especially of success in sport) easily achieved; effortless.
definitions.example: a facile seven-lengths victory
synonyms: as easy as falling off a log

origin: mid 17th century (in the general sense ‘made by human skill or effort’): from Latin facticius ‘made by art’, from facere ‘do, make’.

definitions.definition: artificially created or developed.
definitions.example: a largely factitious national identity

origin: late 15th century: from Old French fallacieux, from Latin fallaciosus, from fallacia (see fallacy).

definitions.definition: based on a mistaken belief.
definitions.example: fallacious arguments

origin: late Middle English: from Latin fastidiosus, from fastidium ‘loathing’. The word originally meant ‘disagreeable’, later ‘disgusted’. Current senses date from the 17th century.

definitions.definition: very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail.
definitions.example: she dressed with fastidious care

definitions.definition: displaying exaggerated flattery or affection; obsequious.
definitions.example: fawning adoration

origin: late Middle English: from Old French faon, based on Latin fetus ‘offspring’; compare with fetus.

definitions.definition: (of a deer) produce young.
definitions.example: the forest was closed for hunting when the does were fawning

origin: Old English fagnian  ‘make or be glad’, of Germanic origin; related to fain.

definitions.definition: (of a person) give a servile display of exaggerated flattery or affection, typically in order to gain favour.
synonyms: lay it on with a trowel

origin: Middle English: from Old French feau(l)te, fealte, from Latin fidelitas (see fidelity).

definitions.definition: a feudal tenant's or vassal's sworn loyalty to a lord.
definitions.example: they owed fealty to the Earl rather than the King

origin: late 16th century: from Scots and northern English dialect feck (from effeck, variant of effect) + -less.

definitions.definition: lacking initiative or strength of character; irresponsible.
definitions.example: her feckless younger brother

origin: late Middle English: from French fécond or Latin fecundus .

definitions.definition: producing or capable of producing an abundance of offspring or new growth; highly fertile.
definitions.example: a lush and fecund garden

definitions.definition: well chosen or suited to the circumstances.
definitions.example: a felicitous phrase

origin: late Middle English: from Old French ferment (noun), fermenter (verb), based on Latin fermentum ‘yeast’, from fervere ‘to boil’.

definitions.definition: (of a substance) undergo fermentation.
definitions.example: the drink had fermented, turning some of the juice into alcohol

definitions.definition: incite or stir up (trouble or disorder).
definitions.example: the politicians and warlords who are fermenting this chaos

definitions.definition: agitation and excitement among a group of people, typically concerning major change and leading to trouble or violence.
definitions.example: a period of political and religious ferment

definitions.definition: a fermenting agent or enzyme.

origin: mid 17th century: from French feston, from Italian festone ‘festal ornament’, from festum, (plural) festa ‘feast’.

definitions.definition: a chain or garland of flowers, leaves, or ribbons, hung in a curve as a decoration.
a Eurasian butterfly or moth patterned with dark arcs on a lighter background.
adorn (a place) with chains, garlands, or other decorations.
definitions.example: the staffroom was festooned with balloons and streamers

origin: early 17th century: from French (see fee).

definitions.definition: an estate of land, especially one held on condition of feudal service; a fee.
a person's sphere of operation or control.

origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘make a fillip with the fingers’): symbolic; compare with flick, flip1.

definitions.definition: something which acts as a stimulus or boost to an activity.
definitions.example: the halving of car tax would provide a fillip to sales

definitions.definition: a movement made by bending the last joint of the finger against the thumb and suddenly releasing it; a flick of the finger.
propel (a small object) with a flick of the fingers.

origin: mid 19th century: from Latin fissus, past participle of findere ‘split’, on the pattern of viviparous .

definitions.definition: inclined to cause or undergo division into separate parts or groups.
definitions.example: the fissiparous tendencies innate in tribalism

definitions.definition: a person who puts together or installs machinery, engine parts, or other equipment.
definitions.example: a qualified gas fitter

definitions.definition: a person who supervises the cutting, fitting, or alteration of garments or shoes.

origin: late Middle English: of unknown origin.

definitions.definition: of a suitable quality, standard, or type to meet the required purpose.
definitions.example: the house was not fit for human habitation

definitions.definition: in good health, especially because of regular physical exercise.
definitions.example: my family keep fit by walking and cycling

origin: early 17th century: from Latin flagellat- ‘whipped’, from flagellare .

definitions.definition: flog (someone), either as a religious discipline or for sexual gratification.
definitions.example: he flagellated himself with branches

origin: mid 19th century: from flagellum + -ate2.

definitions.definition: a protozoan that has one or more flagella used for swimming.
(of a cell or single-celled organism) bearing one or more flagella.
definitions.example: motile flagellate cells

origin: late Middle English: from Latin flagitiosus, from flagitium ‘importunity, shameful crime’, from flagitare ‘demand earnestly’.

definitions.definition: (of a person or their actions) criminal; villainous.

origin: late 15th century (in the sense ‘blazing, resplendent’): from French, or from Latin flagrant- ‘blazing’, from the verb flagrare .

definitions.definition: (of an action considered wrong or immoral) conspicuously or obviously offensive.
definitions.example: a flagrant violation of the law

origin: early 16th century: with biblical allusion to the fleshpots of Egypt (Exod. 16:3).

definitions.definition: places providing luxurious or hedonistic living.
definitions.example: he had lived the life of a roué in the fleshpots of London and Paris

definitions.definition: of, containing, or reminiscent of flint.
definitions.example: flinty soil

origin: early 17th century: from flip1 + -ant, perhaps on the pattern of heraldic terms such as couchant and rampant . Early senses included ‘nimble’ and ‘talkative’, hence ‘playful’, giving rise to the current use ‘lacking seriousness’.

definitions.definition: not showing a serious or respectful attitude.
definitions.example: a flippant remark

origin: mid 16th century: perhaps from Dutch fluiten ‘whistle, play the flute, hiss (in derision)’; German dialect pfeifen auf, literally ‘pipe at’, has a similar extended meaning.

definitions.definition: openly disregard (a rule, law, or convention).
definitions.example: the advertising code is being flouted

definitions.definition: mock; scoff.
definitions.example: the women pointed and flouted at her

origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘palm a false die, so as to produce it at the right moment’): from Dutch dialect vuisten ‘take in the hand’, from vuist (see fist).

definitions.definition: impose an unwelcome or unnecessary person or thing on.
definitions.example: she had no desire to have an elderly relative foisted on her

origin: late Middle English (in foment (sense 2)): from French fomenter, from late Latin fomentare, from Latin fomentum ‘poultice, lotion’, from fovere ‘to heat, cherish’.

definitions.definition: instigate or stir up (an undesirable or violent sentiment or course of action).
definitions.example: they accused him of fomenting political unrest

definitions.definition: bathe (a part of the body) with warm or medicated lotions.

origin: Old English forloren  ‘depraved, morally abandoned’, past participle of forlēosan  ‘lose’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch verliezen and German verlieren, and ultimately to for- and lose. forlorn (sense 1) dates from the 16th century.

definitions.definition: pitifully sad and abandoned or lonely.
definitions.example: forlorn figures at bus stops

definitions.definition: (of an aim or endeavour) unlikely to succeed or be fulfilled.
definitions.example: a forlorn attempt to escape

origin: Old English forswerian  (see for-, swear).

definitions.definition: agree to give up or do without.
definitions.example: the country has not forsworn nuclear weapons

definitions.definition: commit perjury; swear falsely.
definitions.example: I swore that I would lead us safely home and I do not mean to be forsworn

origin: Old English forswerian  (see for-, swear).

definitions.definition: agree to give up or do without.
definitions.example: the country has not forsworn nuclear weapons

definitions.definition: commit perjury; swear falsely.
definitions.example: I swore that I would lead us safely home and I do not mean to be forsworn

origin: mid 17th century: from Latin fortuitus, from forte ‘by chance’, from fors ‘chance, luck’.

definitions.definition: happening by chance rather than intention.
definitions.example: the similarity between the paintings may not be simply fortuitous

origin: late 17th century: from fraction, probably on the pattern of the pair faction, factious .

definitions.definition: (typically of children) irritable and quarrelsome.
definitions.example: they fight and squabble like fractious children
synonyms: like a bear with a sore head

origin: late Middle English, ‘laden, equipped’, past participle of obsolete fraught  ‘load with cargo’, from Middle Dutch vrachten, from vracht ‘ship's cargo’. Compare with freight.

definitions.definition: (of a situation or course of action) filled with or likely to result in (something undesirable).
definitions.example: marketing any new product is fraught with danger

definitions.definition: causing or affected by anxiety or stress.
definitions.example: there was a fraught silence
synonyms: at the end of one's tether

origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘insane’): from Old French frenetique, via Latin from Greek phrenitikos, from phrenitis ‘delirium’, from phrēn ‘mind’. Compare with frantic.

definitions.definition: fast and energetic in a rather wild and uncontrolled way.
definitions.example: a frenetic pace of activity

definitions.definition: feeling or expressing distress or irritation.
definitions.example: the baby was crying with a fretful whimper

origin: late Middle English: from Latin fulminat- ‘struck by lightning’, from fulmen, fulmin- ‘lightning’. The earliest sense (derived from medieval Latin fulminare ) was ‘denounce formally’, later ‘issue formal censures’ (originally said of the Pope). A sense ‘emit thunder and lightning’, based on the original Latin meaning, arose in the early 17th century, and hence ‘explode violently’ (late 17th century).

definitions.definition: express vehement protest.
definitions.example: he fulminated against the evils of his time

definitions.definition: explode violently or flash like lightning.
definitions.example: thunder fulminated around the house

definitions.definition: a salt or ester of fulminic acid.

origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘abundant’): from full1 + -some1.

definitions.definition: complimentary or flattering to an excessive degree.
definitions.example: the press are embarrassingly fulsome in their appreciation

definitions.definition: of large size or quantity; generous or abundant.
definitions.example: the fulsome details of the later legend

origin: early 17th century: from French furtif, -ive or Latin furtivus, from furtum ‘theft’.

definitions.definition: attempting to avoid notice or attention, typically because of guilt or a belief that discovery would lead to trouble; secretive.
definitions.example: they spent a furtive day together

origin: early 20th century: from French, literally ‘boathook’ (from Provençal gaf : see gaff1), used colloquially to mean ‘blunder’.

definitions.definition: an unintentional act or remark causing embarrassment to its originator; a blunder.
definitions.example: in my first few months at work I made some real gaffes
