origin: mid 17th century: originally gambett, from Italian gambetto, literally ‘tripping up’, from gamba ‘leg’.

definitions.definition: an act or remark that is calculated to gain an advantage, especially at the outset of a situation.
definitions.example: his resignation was a tactical gambit

definitions.definition: (in chess) an opening move in which a player makes a sacrifice, typically of a pawn, for the sake of a compensating advantage.
definitions.example: he tried the dubious Budapest gambit

definitions.definition: another term for gangling.

origin: mid 16th century: of unknown origin.

definitions.definition: obtrusively bright and showy; lurid.
definitions.example: garish shirts in all sorts of colours

origin: early 17th century: from Latin garrulus (from garrire ‘to chatter, prattle’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
definitions.example: a garrulous cab driver
synonyms: with the gift of the gab

origin: mid 18th century: French, literally ‘left’.

definitions.definition: unsophisticated and socially awkward.
definitions.example: a shy and gauche teenager

origin: late 15th century: probably from gaud + -y1.

definitions.definition: extravagantly bright or showy, typically so as to be tasteless.
definitions.example: silver bows and gaudy ribbons

origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘rejoicing, a celebration’): from Latin gaudium ‘joy’, or from gaude ‘rejoice!’, imperative of gaudere .

definitions.definition: a celebratory dinner or entertainment held by a college for old members.
definitions.example: administratively, the college cannot cope with more than one gaudy per year

origin: late Middle English: of unknown origin.

definitions.definition: (of a person) lean and haggard, especially because of suffering, hunger, or age.
definitions.example: a tall, gaunt woman in black
synonyms: looking like a bag of bones

origin: early 18th century (as a noun): from gawk + -y1.

definitions.definition: nervously awkward and ungainly.
definitions.example: a gawky teenager

origin: early 17th century: variant of german, with which it was synonymous from Middle English. The current sense has arisen from a usage in Shakespeare's Hamlet .

definitions.definition: relevant to a subject under consideration.
definitions.example: that is not germane to our theme

origin: 1920s: from German Gestalt, literally ‘form, shape’.

definitions.definition: an organized whole that is perceived as more than the sum of its parts.

origin: late 16th century (also in the sense ‘smooth, unimpeded’): ultimately of Germanic origin; related to Dutch ‘slippery’ and German glibberig ‘slimy’.

definitions.definition: (of words or a speaker) fluent but insincere and shallow.
definitions.example: the glib phrases soon roll off the tongue
synonyms: with the gift of the gab

origin: mid 16th century: related to dialect glum ‘to frown’, variant of gloom.

definitions.definition: looking or feeling dejected; morose.
definitions.example: the princess looked glum but later cheered up

origin: early 19th century: from Greek gnōmikos (perhaps via French gnomique ), from gnōmē ‘thought, judgement’, (plural) gnōmai ‘sayings, maxims’, related to gignōskein ‘know’.

definitions.definition: expressed in or of the nature of short, pithy maxims or aphorisms.
definitions.example: that most gnomic form, the aphorism

origin: late 16th century (as a noun): via ecclesiastical Latin from Greek gnōstikos, from gnōstos ‘known’ (related to gignōskein ‘know’).

definitions.definition: relating to knowledge, especially esoteric mystical knowledge.
an adherent of Gnosticism.

origin: mid 17th century: from Latin gregarius (from grex, greg- ‘a flock’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: (of a person) fond of company; sociable.
definitions.example: he was a popular and gregarious man

origin: mid 17th century: from French, from Spanish grimazo ‘caricature’, from grima ‘fright’.

definitions.definition: an ugly, twisted expression on a person's face, typically expressing disgust, pain, or wry amusement.
definitions.example: she gave a grimace of pain

definitions.definition: make a grimace.
definitions.example: I sipped the coffee and grimaced

origin: 1960s: a word invented by Robert Heinlein (1907–88), American author.

definitions.definition: understand (something) intuitively or by empathy.
definitions.example: corporate leaders seemed to grok this concept fairly quickly

origin: early 16th century: perhaps related to medieval Latin gruta or to Old French grue ‘crane’.

definitions.definition: a medium to large game bird with a plump body and feathered legs, the male being larger and more brightly coloured than the female.

origin: early 19th century: of unknown origin; compare with grouch.

definitions.definition: complain about something trivial; grumble.
definitions.example: she heard him grousing about his assistant

definitions.definition: a complaint or grumble.
definitions.example: our biggest grouse was about the noise of construction work

origin: 1920s: of unknown origin.

definitions.definition: very good (used as a general term of approval).
definitions.example: the car was a grouse tomato red which everyone liked

origin: early 18th century (originally Scots): imitative.

definitions.definition: a loud and hearty laugh.
laugh loudly and heartily.
definitions.example: both men guffawed at the remark

origin: Middle English: from Old French, of Germanic origin; related to wise2.

definitions.definition: an external form, appearance, or manner of presentation, typically concealing the true nature of something.
definitions.example: he visited in the guise of an inspector

origin: late 16th century: from French, or from medieval Latin gutturalis, from Latin guttur ‘throat’.

definitions.definition: (of a speech sound) produced in the throat; harsh-sounding.
a guttural consonant (e.g. k, g ) or other speech sound.

origin: mid 18th century: from the archaic verb hackney (see hackney), meaning ‘use (a horse) for ordinary riding’, later ‘make commonplace by overuse’.

definitions.definition: (of a phrase or idea) having been overused; unoriginal and trite.
definitions.example: hackneyed old sayings

origin: mid 16th century (used in falconry): from French hagard ; perhaps related to hedge; later influenced by hag1.

definitions.definition: looking exhausted and unwell, especially from fatigue, worry, or suffering.
definitions.example: she was pale and haggard

definitions.definition: (of a hawk) caught for training as a wild adult of more than twelve months.
a haggard hawk.

origin: late Middle English: from hap1 (in the early sense ‘good fortune’) + -less.

definitions.definition: (especially of a person) unfortunate.
definitions.example: the hapless victims of the disaster

origin: late Middle English: from Old French arenge, from medieval Latin harenga, perhaps of Germanic origin. The spelling was later altered to conform with French harangue (noun), haranguer (verb).

definitions.definition: a lengthy and aggressive speech.
definitions.example: they were subjected to a ten-minute harangue by two border guards

definitions.definition: lecture (someone) at length in an aggressive and critical manner.
definitions.example: he harangued the public on their ignorance

origin: Middle English: from Old French herbergere, from herbergier ‘provide lodging for’, from herberge ‘lodging’, from Old Saxon heriberga ‘shelter for an army, lodging’ (from heri ‘army’ + a Germanic base meaning ‘fortified place’), related to harbour. The term originally denoted a person who provided lodging, later one who went ahead to find lodgings for an army or for a nobleman and his retinue, hence, a herald (mid 16th century).

definitions.definition: a person or thing that announces or signals the approach of another.
definitions.example: witch hazels are the harbingers of spring

origin: mid 16th century: extended form of obsolete haught, earlier haut, from Old French, from Latin altus ‘high’.

definitions.definition: arrogantly superior and disdainful.
definitions.example: a look of haughty disdain

origin: Old English hǣth, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch heide and German Heide .

definitions.definition: an area of open uncultivated land, typically on acid sandy soil, with characteristic vegetation of heather, gorse, and coarse grasses.
definitions.example: horses were being exercised on the heath

definitions.definition: a dwarf shrub with small leathery leaves and small pink or purple bell-shaped flowers, characteristic of heaths and moorland.
a small light brown and orange European butterfly which typically has eyespots on the wings, the caterpillar feeding on grasses.
a yellowish-brown chiefly day-flying European moth of heathland and grassland.

origin: late Middle English: via Old French from ecclesiastical Latin homilia, from Greek, ‘discourse, conversation’ (in ecclesiastical use, ‘sermon’), from homilos ‘crowd’.

definitions.definition: a religious discourse which is intended primarily for spiritual edification rather than doctrinal instruction.
a game in which rings are thrown from behind a line in an attempt to encircle one of several prizes.
unnecessary fuss surrounding something.
definitions.example: I really didn't know what the hoopla was all about

definitions.definition: criticizing or attacking cherished beliefs or institutions.
definitions.example: an iconoclastic filmmaker who has pushed the boundaries with every film he's made

definitions.definition: like an idyll; extremely happy, peaceful, or picturesque.
definitions.example: an attractive hotel in an idyllic setting

origin: late Middle English: from French ignominieux, or Latin ignominiosus, from ignominia (see ignominy).

definitions.definition: deserving or causing public disgrace or shame.
definitions.example: no other party risked ignominious defeat

origin: mid 16th century: from French ignominie or Latin ignominia, from in- ‘not’ + a variant of nomen ‘name’.

definitions.definition: public shame or disgrace.
definitions.example: the ignominy of being imprisoned

origin: late Middle English (in the senses ‘absorb or cause to absorb moisture’ and ‘take into solution’): from Latin imbibere, from in- ‘in’ + bibere ‘to drink’.

definitions.definition: drink (alcohol).
definitions.example: they were imbibing far too many pitchers of beer

origin: mid 16th century: from late Latin immanent- ‘remaining within’, from in- ‘in’ + manere ‘remain’.

definitions.definition: existing or operating within; inherent.
definitions.example: the protection of liberties is immanent in constitutional arrangements

origin: late 16th century: from French emmurer or medieval Latin immurare, from in- ‘in’ + murus ‘wall’.

definitions.definition: enclose or confine (someone) against their will.
definitions.example: her brother was immured in a lunatic asylum

definitions.definition: not feeling or showing emotion.
definitions.example: his cold, impassive face

origin: late 16th century: from in-1 ‘not’ + obsolete pecunious ‘having money, wealthy’ (from Latin pecuniosus, from pecunia ‘money’).

definitions.definition: having little or no money.
definitions.example: a titled but impecunious family

origin: late Middle English: from Old French impetueux, from late Latin impetuosus, from impetere ‘to attack’.

definitions.definition: acting or done quickly and without thought or care.
definitions.example: she might live to rue this impetuous decision

definitions.definition: (of a course of action) impossible in practice to do or carry out.
definitions.example: it was impracticable to widen the road here

origin: mid 18th century: from Italian, from impresa ‘undertaking’.

definitions.definition: a person who organizes and often finances concerts, plays, or operas.
not having or showing foresight; spendthrift or thoughtless.
definitions.example: improvident and undisciplined behaviour

origin: late Middle English (also in the sense ‘assault, attack physically’): from Latin impugnare ‘assail’, from in- ‘towards’ + pugnare ‘fight’.

definitions.definition: dispute the truth, validity, or honesty of (a statement or motive); call into question.
definitions.example: the father does not impugn her capacity as a good mother

origin: mid 16th century: from Latin impunitas, from impunis ‘unpunished’, from in- ‘not’ + poena ‘penalty’ or punire ‘punish’.

definitions.definition: exemption from punishment or freedom from the injurious consequences of an action.
definitions.example: the impunity enjoyed by military officers implicated in civilian killings

origin: mid 16th century: from Latin inanis ‘empty, vain’.

definitions.definition: lacking sense or meaning; silly.
definitions.example: don't badger people with inane questions

definitions.definition: too great to be calculated or estimated.
definitions.example: an archive of incalculable value

definitions.definition: not able to be calculated or estimated.
definitions.example: the odds against such an event are incalculable

origin: late Middle English: from Latin incendiarius, from incendium ‘conflagration’, from incendere ‘set fire to’.

definitions.definition: (of a device or attack) designed to cause fires.
definitions.example: incendiary bombs

definitions.definition: tending to stir up conflict.
definitions.example: incendiary rhetoric

definitions.definition: an incendiary bomb or device.
definitions.example: the Holy City was blasted by incendiaries

definitions.definition: a person who starts fires.
definitions.example: he was an English incendiary, responsible for the burning of three French battleships

origin: mid 16th century: from Latin inchoatus, past participle of inchoare, variant of incohare ‘begin’.

definitions.definition: just begun and so not fully formed or developed; rudimentary.
definitions.example: a still inchoate democracy

definitions.definition: (of an offence, such as incitement or conspiracy) anticipating or preparatory to a further criminal act.

origin: late 16th century (as a noun denoting a beginner): from Latin incipient- ‘undertaking, beginning’, from the verb incipere, from in- ‘into, towards’ + capere ‘take’.

definitions.definition: beginning to happen or develop.
definitions.example: he could feel incipient anger building up

origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘cutting, penetrating’): from medieval Latin incisivus, from Latin incidere ‘cut into’ (see incise).

definitions.definition: (of a person or mental process) intelligently analytical and clear-thinking.
definitions.example: she was an incisive critic

definitions.definition: (of an action) quick and direct.
definitions.example: the most incisive move of a tight match

origin: early 17th century: from French inclément or Latin inclement-, from in- ‘not’ + clement- ‘clement’.

definitions.definition: (of the weather) unpleasantly cold or wet.
definitions.example: walkers should be prepared for inclement weather

origin: early 17th century: from Latin incongruus (from in- ‘not’ + congruus ‘agreeing, suitable’, from the verb congruere ) + -ous.

definitions.definition: not in harmony or keeping with the surroundings or other aspects of something.
definitions.example: the duffel coat looked incongruous with the black dress she wore underneath
synonyms: like a fish out of water

origin: late 17th century: from Latin indecorus (from in- ‘not’ + decorus ‘seemly’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: not in keeping with good taste and propriety; improper.
definitions.example: a pub crawl with sundry indecorous adventures

definitions.definition: not subject to being lost, annulled, or overturned.
definitions.example: an indefeasible right

origin: late 15th century (as indeleble ): from French, or from Latin indelebilis, from in- ‘not’ + delebilis (from delere ‘efface, delete’). The ending was altered under the influence of -ible.

definitions.definition: (of ink or a pen) making marks that cannot be removed.
definitions.example: an indelible marker pen

origin: early 17th century: from Latin indemnis ‘unhurt, free from loss or damage’, from in- (expressing negation) + damnum ‘loss, damage’.

definitions.definition: compensate (someone) for harm or loss.
definitions.example: each of the parties shall indemnify me for all reasonable costs of defending such actions and proceedings

origin: late Middle English: from French indemnite, from late Latin indemnitas, from indemnis ‘unhurt, free from loss’.

definitions.definition: security or protection against a loss or other financial burden.
definitions.example: no indemnity will be given for loss of cash

origin: late Middle English: via Old French from late Latin indigent- ‘lacking’, from the verb indigere, from indi- (strengthened form of in- ‘into’) + egere ‘to need’.

definitions.definition: poor; needy.
definitions.example: a charity for the relief of indigent artists
synonyms: without a penny to one's name
as poor as a church mouse

definitions.definition: a needy person.
avoidance of activity or exertion; laziness.
definitions.example: my failure is probably due to my own indolence

origin: late Middle English: from medieval Latin ineffectualis, from in- ‘not’ + effectualis, from Latin effectus (see effect); in later use from in-1 ‘not’ + effectual.

definitions.definition: not producing any significant or desired effect.
definitions.example: an ineffectual campaign

origin: mid 16th century: from French, or from Latin inexorabilis, from in- ‘not’ + exorabilis (from exorare ‘entreat’).

definitions.definition: impossible to stop or prevent.
definitions.example: the seemingly inexorable march of new technology

origin: early 16th century: from late Latin inimicalis, from Latin inimicus (see enemy).

definitions.definition: tending to obstruct or harm.
definitions.example: the policy was inimical to Britain's real interests

origin: Middle English: from Old French iniquite, from Latin iniquitas, from iniquus, from in- ‘not’ + aequus ‘equal, just’.

definitions.definition: immoral or grossly unfair behaviour.
definitions.example: a den of iniquity

definitions.definition: showing very poor judgement; unwise.
definitions.example: I took a few injudicious swigs of potent cider

origin: late Middle English: from French injurieux or Latin injuriosus, from injuria ‘a wrong’ (see injury).

definitions.definition: causing or likely to cause damage or harm.
definitions.example: food which is injurious to health

origin: late Middle English: from ecclesiastical Latin inscrutabilis, from in- ‘not’ + scrutari ‘to search’ (see scrutiny).

definitions.definition: impossible to understand or interpret.
definitions.example: Guy looked blankly inscrutable

origin: late 15th century: from ecclesiastical Latin insensatus, from in- ‘not’ + sensatus ‘having senses’ (see sensate).

definitions.definition: lacking physical sensation.
definitions.example: a patient who was permanently unconscious and insensate

definitions.definition: completely lacking sense or reason.
definitions.example: insensate jabbering

origin: early 17th century: from French insipide or late Latin insipidus, from in- ‘not’ + sapidus (see sapid).

definitions.definition: lacking flavour; weak or tasteless.
definitions.example: mugs of insipid coffee

origin: late Middle English (also in the sense ‘extravagant, going beyond acceptable limits’): from Latin insolent- ‘immoderate, unaccustomed, arrogant’, from in- ‘not’ + solent- ‘being accustomed’ (from the verb solere ).

definitions.definition: showing a rude and arrogant lack of respect.
definitions.example: she hated the insolent tone of his voice

origin: late 18th century: French, from insouciant, from in- ‘not’ + souciant ‘worrying’ (present participle of soucier ).

definitions.definition: casual lack of concern; indifference.
definitions.example: an impression of boyish insouciance

definitions.definition: defiant of authority; disobedient to orders.
definitions.example: an insubordinate attitude

origin: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘deadly, characterized by great slaughter’): from Latin internecinus, based on inter- ‘among’ + necare ‘to kill’.

definitions.definition: destructive to both sides in a conflict.
definitions.example: the region's history of savage internecine warfare

origin: late 19th century: from French intransigeant, from Spanish los intransigentes (a name adopted by the extreme republicans in the Cortes, 1873–4); based on Latin in- ‘not’ + transigere ‘come to an understanding’.

definitions.definition: unwilling or refusing to change one's views or to agree about something.
definitions.example: her father had tried persuasion, but she was intransigent

definitions.definition: an intransigent person.

origin: late 17th century: from French intrépide or Latin intrepidus, from in- ‘not’ + trepidus ‘alarmed’.

definitions.definition: fearless; adventurous (often used for rhetorical or humorous effect).
definitions.example: our intrepid reporter

origin: late 16th century: (earlier (late Middle English) as inundation ) from Latin inundat- ‘flooded’, from the verb inundare, from in- ‘into, upon’ + undare ‘to flow’ (from unda ‘a wave’).

definitions.definition: overwhelm (someone) with things or people to be dealt with.
definitions.example: we've been inundated with complaints from listeners

definitions.definition: flood.
definitions.example: the islands may be the first to be inundated as sea levels rise

origin: late Middle English inure, enure, from an Anglo-Norman French phrase meaning ‘in use or practice’, from en ‘in’ + Old French euvre ‘work’ (from Latin opera ).

definitions.definition: accustom (someone) to something, especially something unpleasant.
definitions.example: these children have been inured to violence

definitions.definition: variant spelling of enure (sense 1).

origin: late Middle English (originally as an adjective meaning ‘reviling, abusive’): from Old French invectif, -ive, from late Latin invectivus ‘attacking’, from invehere (see inveigh). The noun is from late Latin invectiva (oratio) ‘abusive or censorious (language)’.

definitions.definition: insulting, abusive, or highly critical language.
definitions.example: he let out a stream of invective

origin: late Middle English (referring to disease, in the sense ‘of long standing, chronic’): from Latin inveteratus ‘made old’, past participle of inveterare (based on vetus, veter- ‘old’).

definitions.definition: having a particular habit, activity, or interest that is long-established and unlikely to change.
definitions.example: an inveterate gambler

origin: late Middle English: via French from late Latin irascibilis, from Latin irasci ‘grow angry’, from ira ‘anger’.

definitions.definition: having or showing a tendency to be easily angered.
definitions.example: an irascible and difficult man

origin: mid 19th century: from Latin iratus, from ira ‘anger’.

definitions.definition: feeling or characterized by great anger.
definitions.example: a barrage of irate letters

definitions.definition: a lack of respect for people or things that are generally taken seriously.
definitions.example: an attitude of irreverence towards politicians

origin: late Middle English (as a noun denoting the throwing of goods overboard to lighten a ship in distress): from Old French getaison, from Latin jactatio(n- ), from jactare ‘to throw’ (see jet1). The verb dates from the mid 19th century.

definitions.definition: throw or drop (something) from an aircraft or ship.
definitions.example: six aircraft jettisoned their loads in the sea

definitions.definition: the action of jettisoning something.
definitions.example: the jettison lever

definitions.definition: extreme patriotism, especially in the form of aggressive or warlike foreign policy.
definitions.example: the popular jingoism that swept the lower–middle classes

origin: late 17th century (in the sense ‘broker, middleman’, originally not derogatory): from job1.

definitions.definition: (in the UK) a principal or wholesaler who dealt only on the Stock Exchange with brokers, not directly with the public.
a wholesaler.
a person who does casual or occasional work.

origin: late 16th century: diminutive of Jock. Originally the name for an ordinary man, lad, or underling, the word came to mean ‘mounted courier’, hence the current sense (late 17th century). Another early use ‘horse-dealer’ (long a byword for dishonesty) probably gave rise to the verb sense ‘manipulate’, whereas the main verb sense probably relates to the behaviour of jockeys manoeuvring for an advantageous position during a race.

definitions.definition: a person who rides in horse races, especially as a profession.
definitions.example: a former champion jockey

definitions.definition: struggle by every available means to gain or achieve something.
definitions.example: both men will be jockeying for the two top jobs

origin: late 16th century: from French, from late Latin jovialis ‘of Jupiter’ (see Jove), with reference to the supposed influence of the planet Jupiter on those born under it.

definitions.definition: cheerful and friendly.
definitions.example: she was in a jovial mood
synonyms: without a care in the world
full of the joys of spring

definitions.definition: a feeling of great happiness and triumph.
definitions.example: unbelievable scenes of jubilation

origin: early 17th century: from late Latin jurisprudentia, from Latin jus, jur- ‘law’ + prudentia ‘knowledge’.

definitions.definition: the theory or philosophy of law.

origin: early 19th century: perhaps from Scots curfuffle (probably from Scottish Gaelic car ‘twist, bend’ + imitative Scots fuffle ‘to disorder’), or related to Irish cior thual ‘confusion, disorder’.

definitions.definition: a commotion or fuss, especially one caused by conflicting views.
definitions.example: there was a kerfuffle over the chairmanship

origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘Laconian’): via Latin from Greek Lakōnikos, from Lakōn ‘Laconia, Sparta’, the Spartans being known for their terse speech.

definitions.definition: (of a person, speech, or style of writing) using very few words.
definitions.example: his laconic reply suggested a lack of interest in the topic

origin: mid 17th century: from Latin, ‘pool’, from lacus ‘lake’.

definitions.definition: an unfilled space; a gap.
definitions.example: the journal has filled a lacuna in Middle Eastern studies

definitions.definition: a cavity or depression, especially in bone.

origin: Louisiana French, from Spanish la ñapa .

definitions.definition: something given as a bonus or gratuity.

origin: French.

definitions.definition: a strong, sweet Belgian beer.
(of a person) ungracefully thin and tall.

origin: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin largus ‘copious’.

definitions.definition: generosity in bestowing money or gifts upon others.
definitions.example: presumably public money is not dispensed with such largesse to anyone else

origin: late Middle English: from late Latin lasciviosus, from Latin lascivia ‘lustfulness’, from lascivus ‘lustful, wanton’.

definitions.definition: feeling or revealing an overt sexual interest or desire.
definitions.example: he gave her a lascivious wink

origin: late Middle English: the noun from Old French laude, the verb from Latin laudare, both from Latin laus, laud- ‘praise’ (see also lauds).

definitions.definition: praise (a person or their achievements) highly.
definitions.example: the obituary lauded him as a great statesman and soldier

definitions.definition: praise.
definitions.example: all glory, laud, and honour to Thee Redeemer King

origin: mid 16th century: from late Latin laudatorius, from laudat- ‘praised’, from the verb laudare (see laud).

definitions.definition: (of speech or writing) expressing praise and commendation.
definitions.example: enthusiastic and laudatory articles

definitions.definition: (of bread) made with yeast or other raising agent.
definitions.example: leavened breads are forbidden during Passover

origin: Middle English: from Old French levain, based on Latin levamen ‘relief’ (literally ‘means of raising’), from levare ‘to lift’.

definitions.definition: cause (dough or bread) to rise by adding yeast or another raising agent.
definitions.example: it only take a little bit of yeast to leaven the bread

definitions.definition: permeate and modify or transform (something) for the better.
definitions.example: the proceedings should be leavened by humour

origin: late Middle English: from French léger de main ‘dexterous’, literally ‘light of hand’.

definitions.definition: skilful use of one's hands when performing conjuring tricks.

origin: Old English lǣwede, of unknown origin. The original sense was ‘belonging to the laity’; in Middle English, ‘belonging to the common people, vulgar’, and later ‘worthless, vile, evil’, leading to the current sense.

definitions.definition: crude and offensive in a sexual way.
definitions.example: she began to gyrate to the music and sing a lewd song

origin: Middle English (in the general sense ‘a document, a written statement’): via Old French from Latin libellus, diminutive of liber ‘book’.

definitions.definition: a published false statement that is damaging to a person's reputation; a written defamation.
definitions.example: he was found guilty of a libel on a Liverpool inspector of taxes

definitions.definition: (in admiralty and ecclesiastical law) a plaintiff's written declaration.
defame (someone) by publishing a libel.
definitions.example: the jury found that he was libelled by a newspaper

definitions.definition: (in admiralty and ecclesiastical law) bring a suit against.
definitions.example: if a ship does you any injury you libel the ship

origin: late Middle English (denoting a freed slave or the son of one): from Latin libertinus ‘freedman’, from liber ‘free’. In the mid 16th century, imitating French libertin, the term denoted a member of any of various antinomian sects in France; hence libertine (sense 2 of the noun).

definitions.definition: a person, especially a man, who freely indulges in sensual pleasures without regard to moral principles.
definitions.example: his image as an unbridled libertine is a total myth

definitions.definition: a freethinker in matters of religion.
characterized by free indulgence in sensual pleasures.
definitions.example: his more libertine impulses

definitions.definition: freethinking.

origin: late Middle English: from Latin libidinosus, from libido ‘desire, lust’.

definitions.definition: showing excessive sexual drive; lustful.
definitions.example: libidinous teenagers

origin: late Middle English: from Latin licentiosus, from licentia ‘freedom’.

definitions.definition: promiscuous and unprincipled in sexual matters.
definitions.example: the ruler's tyrannical and licentious behaviour

definitions.definition: disregarding accepted conventions, especially in grammar or literary style.
give a lot of public attention and approval to (someone); treat as a celebrity.
definitions.example: modern sportsmen are lionized and feted

origin: Middle English: from Old French letanie, via ecclesiastical Latin from Greek litaneia ‘prayer’, from litē ‘supplication’.

definitions.definition: a series of petitions for use in church services or processions, usually recited by the clergy and responded to in a recurring formula by the people.
a tedious recital or repetitive series.
definitions.example: a litany of complaints

origin: mid 17th century: from French, from Latin litigant- ‘carrying on a lawsuit’, from the verb litigare (see litigate).

definitions.definition: a person involved in a lawsuit.
involved in a lawsuit.
definitions.example: the parties litigant

origin: late Middle English: from Old French litigieux or Latin litigiosus from litigium ‘litigation’, from lis, lit- ‘lawsuit’.

definitions.definition: tending or too ready to take legal action to settle disputes.
definitions.example: our increasingly litigious society

origin: Old English lāth  ‘hostile, spiteful’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch leed, German Leid ‘sorrow’.

definitions.definition: reluctant; unwilling.
definitions.example: I was loath to leave

origin: Old English lāthian, of Germanic origin; related to loath.

definitions.definition: feel intense dislike or disgust for.
definitions.example: she loathed him on sight

origin: mid 17th century: from Latin loquax, loquac- (from loqui ‘talk’) + -ious.

definitions.definition: tending to talk a great deal; talkative.
definitions.example: never loquacious, Sarah was now totally lost for words
synonyms: with the gift of the gab

origin: late Middle English: from French lucre or Latin lucrum ; the phrase filthy lucre is with biblical allusion to Tit. 1:11.

definitions.definition: money, especially when regarded as sordid or distasteful or gained in a dishonourable way.
definitions.example: officials getting their hands grubby with filthy lucre

origin: early 19th century: perhaps named after Ned Lud, a participant in the destruction of machinery, + -ite1.

definitions.definition: a person opposed to new technology or ways of working.
definitions.example: a small-minded Luddite resisting progress

definitions.definition: a member of any of the bands of English workers who destroyed machinery, especially in cotton and woollen mills, that they believed was threatening their jobs (1811–16).
opposed to new technology or ways of working.
definitions.example: this bill is really a Luddite approach to science

definitions.definition: denoting or relating to the 19th-century Luddites who destroyed machinery that they believed was threatening their jobs.
definitions.example: the Luddite movement

origin: early 17th century: from Latin lugubris (from lugere ‘mourn’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: looking or sounding sad and dismal.
definitions.example: his face looked even more lugubrious than usual

origin: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘pale and dismal in colour’): from Latin luridus ; related to luror ‘wan or yellow colour’.

definitions.definition: unpleasantly bright in colour, especially so as to create a harsh or unnatural effect.
definitions.example: lurid food colourings

origin: mid 16th century: from Latin magnanimus (from magnus ‘great’ + animus ‘soul’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: generous or forgiving, especially towards a rival or less powerful person.
definitions.example: she should be magnanimous in victory

origin: Middle English: via Old French maligne (adjective), malignier (verb), based on Latin malignus ‘tending to evil’, from malus ‘bad’.

definitions.definition: evil in nature or effect.
definitions.example: she had a strong and malign influence

definitions.definition: speak about (someone) in a spitefully critical manner.
definitions.example: don't you dare malign her in my presence

origin: Middle English: from Old French manicle ‘handcuff’, from Latin manicula, diminutive of manus ‘hand’.

definitions.definition: one of two metal bands joined by a chain, for fastening a person's hands or ankles.
definitions.example: the practice of keeping prisoners in manacles

definitions.definition: confine (a person or part of the body) with manacles.
definitions.example: his hands were manacled behind his back

origin: Middle English: from Old French (peau) martrine ‘marten (fur)’, from martre, of West Germanic origin.

definitions.definition: a semi-arboreal weasel-like mammal found in Eurasia and North America, hunted for its fur in some countries.

origin: late 17th century (denoting the system of drill invented by Martinet): named after Jean Martinet, 17th-century French drill master.

definitions.definition: a person who demands complete obedience; a strict disciplinarian.
definitions.example: the woman in charge was a martinet who treated all those beneath her like children

origin: late Middle English (as a noun denoting Mary Magdalen): from Old French Madeleine, from Church Latin Magdalena (see magdalen). The current sense derives from allusion to pictures of Mary Magdalen weeping.

definitions.definition: self-pityingly or tearfully sentimental.
definitions.example: a bout of maudlin self-pity

origin: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘inclined to sickness’): from obsolete mawk ‘maggot’, from Old Norse mathkr, of Germanic origin.

definitions.definition: sentimental in an exaggerated or false way.
definitions.example: a mawkish ode to parenthood

origin: late 15th century: from late Latin mellifluus (from mel ‘honey’ + fluere ‘to flow’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: (of a sound) pleasingly smooth and musical to hear.
definitions.example: her low mellifluous voice

origin: late Middle English: from Latin, literally ‘something to be brought to mind’, gerundive of memorare . The original use was as an adjective, placed at the head of a note of a record made for future reference.

definitions.definition: a written message in business or diplomacy.
definitions.example: he told them of his decision in a memorandum

origin: mid 17th century: from ecclesiastical Latin mendacitas, from mendax, mendac- ‘lying’ (see mendacious).

definitions.definition: untruthfulness.
definitions.example: people publicly castigated for past mendacity

origin: late Middle English (in mercurial (sense 3 of the adjective)): from Latin mercurialis ‘relating to the god Mercury’, from Mercurius ‘Mercury’. mercurial (sense 1 of the adjective) dates from the mid 17th century.

definitions.definition: subject to sudden or unpredictable changes of mood or mind.
definitions.example: his mercurial temperament

definitions.definition: of or containing the element mercury.
definitions.example: gels containing organic mercurial compounds

definitions.definition: of the planet Mercury.
a drug or other compound containing mercury.
definitions.example: for twenty years organic mercurials were the most potent diuretics in clinical use

origin: late Middle English (as adverb and noun): from legal French, variant of Anglo-Norman French meen ‘middle’ (see mean3).

definitions.definition: intermediate or intervening.

origin: mid 17th century: from Greek, literally ‘defilement’, from miainein ‘pollute’.

definitions.definition: an unpleasant or unhealthy smell or vapour.
definitions.example: a miasma of stale alcohol hung around him

origin: early 16th century: probably from French mine ‘expression’, influenced by obsolete demean  ‘bearing, demeanour’ (from demean2).

definitions.definition: a person's appearance or manner, especially as an indication of their character or mood.
definitions.example: he has a cautious, academic mien

definitions.definition: another term for Yao2.

origin: mid 19th century: French, from mi ‘mid’ + lieu ‘place’.

definitions.definition: a person's social environment.
definitions.example: Gregory came from the same aristocratic milieu as Sidonius

origin: mid 16th century: from Greek misanthrōpos, from misein ‘to hate’ + anthrōpos ‘man’.

definitions.definition: a person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society.
definitions.example: Scrooge wasn't the mean-spirited misanthrope most of us believe him to be

origin: late 15th century (as an adjective in the sense ‘miserly’): from Latin, literally ‘wretched’.

definitions.definition: a person who hoards wealth and spends as little money as possible.
definitions.example: a typical miser, he hid his money in the house in various places

origin: late 15th century: from Latin, neuter of modicus ‘moderate’, from modus ‘measure’.

definitions.definition: a small quantity of a particular thing, especially something desirable or valuable.
definitions.example: his statement had a modicum of truth

origin: late Middle English: from Old French moite, from Latin medietas ‘middle’, from medius ‘mid, middle’.

definitions.definition: each of two parts into which a thing is or can be divided.
definitions.example: the tax was to be delivered in two moieties

origin: late 15th century: from Dutch moeras, alteration (by assimilation to moer ‘moor’) of Middle Dutch marasch, from Old French marais ‘marsh’, from medieval Latin mariscus .

definitions.definition: an area of muddy or boggy ground.
definitions.example: in midwinter the track beneath this bridge became a muddy morass

definitions.definition: a complicated or confused situation.
definitions.example: she would become lost in a morass of lies and explanations

origin: early 18th century: from Latin moribundus, from mori ‘to die’.

definitions.definition: (of a person) at the point of death.
definitions.example: on examination she was moribund and dehydrated
synonyms: with one foot in the grave

origin: mid 16th century: from Latin morosus ‘peevish’, from mos, mor- ‘manner’.

definitions.definition: sullen and ill-tempered.
definitions.example: she was morose and silent when she got home

origin: Old English mot, related to Dutch mot ‘dust, sawdust’.

definitions.definition: a tiny piece of a substance; a speck.
definitions.example: the tiniest mote of dust

origin: late Middle English: of unknown origin; perhaps ultimately related to mote.

definitions.definition: incongruously varied in appearance or character; disparate.
definitions.example: a motley crew of discontents and zealots

definitions.definition: (of clothing) made up of a variety of colours.
definitions.example: they wore the motley coat of jesters

definitions.definition: an incongruous mixture.
definitions.example: a motley of interacting interest groups

definitions.definition: the multicoloured costume of a jester.
definitions.example: life-size mannequins in full motley

origin: late 16th century: from Latin munificent- (stem of munificentior, comparative of munificus ‘bountiful’), from munus ‘gift’.

definitions.definition: characterized by or displaying great generosity.
definitions.example: a munificent bequest

origin: late Middle English: from Latin Myrmidones (plural), from Greek Murmidones, a warlike Thessalian people who accompanied Achilles to Troy.

definitions.definition: a follower or subordinate of a powerful person, typically one who is unscrupulous or carries out orders unquestioningly.
definitions.example: one of Hitler's myrmidons

origin: late Middle English (in nadir (sense 2 of the noun)): via French from Arabic naẓīr (as-samt) ‘opposite (to the zenith)’.

definitions.definition: the lowest or most unsuccessful point in a situation.
definitions.example: asking that question was the nadir of my career
synonyms: as low as one can get

definitions.definition: the point on the celestial sphere directly below an observer.

origin: late Middle English: via ecclesiastical Latin from Greek neophutos, literally ‘newly planted’ but first used in the sense ‘new convert’ by St Paul (1 Tim. 3:6), from neos ‘new’ + phuton ‘plant’.

definitions.definition: a person who is new to a subject or activity.
definitions.example: four-day cooking classes are offered to neophytes and experts

definitions.definition: a new convert to a religion.

origin: Old English netle, netele, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch netel and German Nessel . The verb dates from late Middle English.

definitions.definition: a herbaceous plant which has jagged leaves covered with stinging hairs.
irritate or annoy (someone).
definitions.example: ‘I was only asking,’ Jess said, nettled

definitions.definition: sting with nettles.

origin: late Middle English: alteration of earlier nigon, probably of Scandinavian origin.

definitions.definition: a mean or ungenerous person; a miser.
ungenerous; niggardly.

origin: late Middle English: from obsolete noy (shortened form of annoy) + -some1.

definitions.definition: having an extremely offensive smell.
definitions.example: noisome vapours from the smouldering waste

origin: late 16th century: from medieval Latin nonentitas ‘non-existence’.

definitions.definition: a person or thing with no special or interesting qualities; an unimportant person or thing.
definitions.example: a political nonentity

definitions.definition: non-existence.
definitions.example: asserting the nonentity of evil

definitions.definition: so surprised and confused that one is unsure how to react.
definitions.example: Henry looked completely nonplussed

definitions.definition: not disconcerted; unperturbed.

origin: late 16th century: from Latin non plus ‘not more’. The noun originally meant ‘a state in which no more can be said or done’.

definitions.definition: surprise and confuse (someone) so much that they are unsure how to react.
definitions.example: Diane was nonplussed by such an odd question

origin: early 17th century: from Latin, used in the sense ‘(something) of our own making’, neuter of noster ‘our’.

definitions.definition: a medicine prepared by an unqualified person, especially one that is not considered effective.
definitions.example: a charlatan who sells nostrums

origin: late Middle English: from not + withstanding, present participle of withstand, on the pattern of Old French non obstant ‘not providing an obstacle to’.

definitions.definition: in spite of.
definitions.example: notwithstanding the evidence, the consensus is that the jury will not reach a verdict

definitions.definition: nevertheless; in spite of this.
definitions.example: I didn't like it. Notwithstanding, I remained calm
synonyms: when all is said and done

definitions.definition: although; in spite of the fact that.
definitions.example: notwithstanding that the hall was packed with bullies, our champion played on steadily and patiently
synonyms: in spite of the fact that

origin: late 15th century: from Latin noxius (from noxa ‘harm’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: harmful, poisonous, or very unpleasant.
definitions.example: they were overcome by the noxious fumes

origin: late Middle English (originally in the sense ‘hardened in sin, impenitent’): from Latin obduratus, past participle of obdurare, from ob- ‘in opposition’ + durare ‘harden’ (from durus ‘hard’).

definitions.definition: stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action.
definitions.example: I argued this point with him, but he was obdurate

origin: late Middle English: from late Latin obloquium ‘contradiction’, from Latin obloqui, from ob- ‘against’ + loqui ‘speak’.

definitions.definition: strong public condemnation.
definitions.example: he endured years of contempt and obloquy

origin: mid 17th century: from Latin obtrus- ‘thrust forward’, from the verb obtrudere (see obtrude).

definitions.definition: noticeable or prominent in an unwelcome or intrusive way.
definitions.example: a large and obtrusive works where ammonia is produced

origin: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘turned towards the observer’): from Latin obversus, past participle of obvertere ‘turn towards’ (see obvert).

definitions.definition: the side of a coin or medal bearing the head or principal design.
the opposite or counterpart of a fact or truth.
definitions.example: true solitude is the obverse of true society

definitions.definition: of or denoting the obverse of a coin or medal.
corresponding to something else as its opposite or counterpart.
definitions.example: the obverse fates of the principals

definitions.definition: narrower at the base or point of attachment than at the apex or top.
definitions.example: an obverse leaf

origin: late 16th century: from late Latin obviat- ‘prevented’, from the verb obviare, based on Latin via ‘way’.

definitions.definition: remove (a need or difficulty).
definitions.example: the presence of roller blinds obviated the need for curtains

origin: late 16th century: from Latin occludere ‘shut up’.

definitions.definition: stop, close up, or obstruct (an opening, orifice, or passage).
definitions.example: thick make-up can occlude the pores

definitions.definition: (of a tooth) come into contact with another tooth in the opposite jaw.
definitions.example: in monkeys and apes, the upper canine occludes with the lower first premolar

definitions.definition: (of a solid) absorb and retain (a gas or impurity).
definitions.example: occluded within these crystals are other molecules

origin: late 15th century (as a verb): from Latin occultare ‘secrete’, frequentative of occulere ‘conceal’, based on celare ‘to hide’; the adjective and noun from occult- ‘covered over’, from the verb occulere .

definitions.definition: mystical, supernatural, or magical powers, practices, or phenomena.
definitions.example: a secret society to study alchemy and the occult

definitions.definition: involving or relating to mystical, supernatural, or magical powers, practices, or phenomena.
definitions.example: an occult ceremony

definitions.definition: (of a disease or process) not accompanied by readily discernible signs or symptoms.
definitions.example: careful palpation sometimes discloses occult spina bifida

definitions.definition: cut off from view by interposing something.
definitions.example: a wooden screen designed to occult the competitors

origin: late 16th century: from late Latin ocularis, from Latin oculus ‘eye’.

definitions.definition: of or connected with the eyes or vision.
definitions.example: ocular trauma

definitions.definition: another term for eyepiece.

origin: late 17th century: from French, from Turkish odalik, from oda ‘chamber’ + lik ‘function’.

definitions.definition: a female slave or concubine in a harem, especially one in the seraglio of the Sultan of Turkey.

origin: late Middle English: from late Latin opprobriosus, from opprobrium (see opprobrium).

definitions.definition: (of language) expressing scorn or criticism.
definitions.example: opprobrious remarks

origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘wealthy’): from Latin opulent- ‘wealthy, splendid’, from opes ‘wealth’.

definitions.definition: ostentatiously costly and luxurious.
definitions.example: the opulent comfort of a limousine

origin: mid 18th century: from French, from medieval Latin ostensibilis from Latin ostens- ‘stretched out to view’, from the verb ostendere, from ob- ‘in view of’ + tendere ‘to stretch’.

definitions.definition: stated or appearing to be true, but not necessarily so.
definitions.example: the real dispute which lay behind the ostensible complaint

origin: mid 18th century: from Latin palatium ‘palace’ (see palace) + -al.

definitions.definition: resembling a palace in being spacious and splendid.
definitions.example: her palatial apartment in Mayfair

definitions.definition: relating to or denoting the neoclassical style of Andrea Palladio, in particular with reference to the phase of English architecture from c. 1715, when there was a revival of interest in Palladio and his English follower, Inigo Jones, and a reaction against the baroque.

origin: late Middle English (as an adjective): from French palliatif, -ive or medieval Latin palliativus, from the verb palliare ‘to cloak’ (see palliate).

definitions.definition: (of a medicine or medical care) relieving pain without dealing with the cause of the condition.
definitions.example: orthodox medicines tend to be palliative rather than curative

definitions.definition: a palliative medicine, measure, etc.
definitions.example: antibiotics and other palliatives

origin: mid 16th century: apparently based on dialect pelt  ‘rubbish, especially rags’; compare with Low German paltrig ‘ragged’.

definitions.definition: (of an amount) very small or meagre.
definitions.example: she would earn a paltry £33 more a month

origin: mid 16th century: via Latin from Greek panakeia, from panakēs ‘all-healing’, from pan ‘all’ + akos ‘remedy’.

definitions.definition: a solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases.
definitions.example: the panacea for all corporate ills

origin: mid 16th century: from French, from Italian pennacchio, from late Latin pinnaculum, diminutive of pinna ‘feather’.

definitions.definition: flamboyant confidence of style or manner.
definitions.example: he entertained London society with great panache

definitions.definition: a tuft or plume of feathers, especially as a headdress or on a helmet.

origin: late 16th century (in the sense ‘complete protection for spiritual warfare’, often with biblical allusion to Eph. 6:11, 13): from French panoplie or modern Latin panoplia ‘full armour’, from Greek, from pan ‘all’ + hopla ‘arms’.

definitions.definition: an extensive or impressive collection.
definitions.example: a deliciously inventive panoply of insults

origin: mid 18th century: from pan- ‘all’ + Greek optikon, neuter of optikos ‘optic’.

definitions.definition: a circular prison with cells arranged around a central well, from which prisoners could at all times be observed.

origin: late 16th century (first used in the Latin form and denoting an actor using mime): from French pantomime or Latin pantomimus, from Greek pantomimos ‘imitator of all’ (see panto-, mime).

definitions.definition: a theatrical entertainment, mainly for children, which involves music, topical jokes, and slapstick comedy and is based on a fairy tale or nursery story, usually produced around Christmas.
definitions.example: a pantomime villain

definitions.definition: a dramatic entertainment, originating in Roman mime, in which performers express meaning through gestures accompanied by music.
an absurdly exaggerated piece of behaviour.
definitions.example: he made a pantomime of checking his watch

definitions.definition: express or represent by exaggerated mime.
definitions.example: they pantomimed picking up dropped food

origin: mid 16th century: from obsolete French, from Italian paragone ‘touchstone to try good (gold) from bad’, from medieval Greek parakonē ‘whetstone’.

definitions.definition: a person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a particular quality.
definitions.example: it would have taken a paragon of virtue not to feel viciously jealous

origin: early 17th century: from Tamil paṛaiyar, plural of paṛaiyan ‘(hereditary) drummer’, from paṛai ‘a drum’.

definitions.definition: an outcast.
definitions.example: they were treated as social pariahs

definitions.definition: a member of an indigenous people of southern India originally functioning as ceremonial drummers but later having a low caste.

origin: late Middle English: from Old French, from ecclesiastical Latin parochialis ‘relating to an ecclesiastical district’, from parochia (see parish).

definitions.definition: relating to a Church parish.
definitions.example: the parochial church council

definitions.definition: having a limited or narrow outlook or scope.
definitions.example: parochial attitudes

origin: late Middle English: from French paroxysme, via medieval Latin from Greek paroxusmos, from paroxunein ‘exasperate’, from para- ‘beyond’ + oxunein ‘sharpen’ (from oxus ‘sharp’).

definitions.definition: a sudden attack or outburst of a particular emotion or activity.
definitions.example: a paroxysm of weeping

origin: late 16th century: from French, from Latin parricidium ‘murder of a parent’, with first element of unknown origin, but for long associated with Latin pater ‘father’ and parens ‘parent’.

definitions.definition: the killing of a parent or other near relative.
very unwilling to spend money or use resources.
definitions.example: even the parsimonious Joe paid for drinks all round

origin: late 19th century: from French, from Italian pasticcio, based on late Latin pasta ‘paste’.

definitions.definition: an artistic work in a style that imitates that of another work, artist, or period.
definitions.example: the operetta is a pastiche of 18th century style

definitions.definition: imitate the style of (an artist or work).
definitions.example: Gauguin took himself to a Pacific island and pastiched the primitive art he found there

origin: late Middle English: from Old French patricien, from Latin patricius ‘having a noble father’, from pater, patr- ‘father’.

definitions.definition: an aristocrat or nobleman.
belonging to or characteristic of the aristocracy.
definitions.example: a proud, patrician face

origin: late Middle English: from Old French paucite or Latin paucitas, from paucus ‘few’.

definitions.definition: the presence of something in only small or insufficient quantities or amounts.
definitions.example: a paucity of information

origin: late 16th century: from Spanish pecadillo, diminutive of pecado ‘sin’, from Latin peccare ‘to sin’.

definitions.definition: a relatively minor fault or sin.
definitions.example: the sexual peccadilloes of celebrities aren't necessarily news

origin: early 17th century: from modern Latin paederastia, from Greek paiderastia, from pais, paid- ‘boy’ + erastēs ‘lover’.

definitions.definition: sexual activity involving a man and a boy or youth.

origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘perverse, coy’): of unknown origin.

definitions.definition: having or showing an irritable disposition.
definitions.example: a thin peevish voice
synonyms: like a bear with a sore head

origin: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin paenitentia ‘repentance’, from the verb paenitere ‘be sorry’.

definitions.definition: punishment inflicted on oneself as an outward expression of repentance for wrongdoing.
definitions.example: he had done public penance for those hasty words

definitions.definition: a sacrament in which a member of the Church confesses sins to a priest and is given absolution.
impose a penance on.
definitions.example: the Bishop penanced him severely for his conduct

origin: late 15th century: from late Latin paenitentialis, from Latin paenitentia ‘repentance’.

definitions.definition: relating to or expressing penitence or penance.
definitions.example: penitential tears

origin: late 17th century: from Latin paenultimus, from paene ‘almost’ + ultimus ‘last’, on the pattern of ultimate .

definitions.definition: last but one in a series of things; second last.
definitions.example: the penultimate chapter of the book

origin: late 16th century: from medieval Latin penuriosus, from Latin penuria ‘need, scarcity’ (see penury).

definitions.definition: extremely poor; poverty-stricken.
definitions.example: a penurious old tramp
synonyms: as poor as a church mouse

definitions.definition: unwilling to spend money; mean.
definitions.example: a tight-fisted, penurious boss whose wage scale is well below other bandleaders

origin: late 16th century: from Latin perfidiosus, from perfidia ‘treachery’.

definitions.definition: deceitful and untrustworthy.
definitions.example: a perfidious lover

origin: late 16th century: from late Latin perfunctorius ‘careless’, from Latin perfunct- ‘done with, discharged’, from the verb perfungi .

definitions.definition: (of an action) carried out without real interest, feeling, or effort.
definitions.example: he gave a perfunctory nod

origin: early 17th century: from Latin perspicax, perspicac- ‘seeing clearly’ + -acious.

definitions.definition: having a ready insight into and understanding of things.
definitions.example: it offers quite a few facts to the perspicacious reporter

origin: early 17th century: from Latin pertinax, pertinac- ‘holding fast’ + -ous.

definitions.definition: holding firmly to an opinion or a course of action.
definitions.example: he worked with a pertinacious resistance to interruptions

origin: late 15th century (in the sense ‘use up, wear out’): perhaps from per- ‘thoroughly’ + use, but compare with Anglo-Norman French peruser ‘examine’.

definitions.definition: read (something), typically in a thorough or careful way.
definitions.example: he has spent countless hours in libraries perusing art history books and catalogues

origin: mid 17th century: from Latin pervicax, pervicac- ‘stubborn’ (from pervincere ‘conquer’) + -ious.

definitions.definition: very obstinate or stubborn; headstrong.

origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘morally corrupting’): from Latin pestifer ‘bringing pestilence’ + -ous.

definitions.definition: harbouring infection and disease.
definitions.example: the pestiferous area around the prison

definitions.definition: relating to or tending to cause infectious diseases.
definitions.example: pestilential fever

origin: early 17th century: back-formation from pettifogger.

definitions.definition: quibble about petty points.

origin: mid 16th century (denoting a body of Macedonian infantry): via Latin from Greek.

definitions.definition: a body of troops or police officers standing or moving in close formation.
definitions.example: six hundred marchers set off, led by a phalanx of police

definitions.definition: a bone of the finger or toe.

origin: early 19th century (originally the name of a London exhibition (1802) of optical illusions produced chiefly by magic lantern): probably from French fantasmagorie, from fantasme ‘phantasm’ + a fanciful suffix.

definitions.definition: a sequence of real or imaginary images like that seen in a dream.
definitions.example: what happened next was a phantasmagoria of horror and mystery

origin: mid 18th century: from the earlier noun philander  ‘man, husband’, often used in literature as the given name of a lover, from Greek philandros ‘fond of men’, from philein ‘to love’ + anēr ‘man’.

definitions.definition: (of a man) readily or frequently enter into casual sexual relationships with women.
definitions.example: married men who philander

origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘relating to the humour phlegm’): from Old French fleumatique, via Latin from Greek phlegmatikos, from phlegma ‘inflammation’ (see phlegm).

definitions.definition: (of a person) having an unemotional and stolidly calm disposition.
definitions.example: the phlegmatic British character

origin: early 19th century: from French, from Spanish picaresco, from pícaro ‘rogue’.

definitions.definition: relating to an episodic style of fiction dealing with the adventures of a rough and dishonest but appealing hero.
definitions.example: a picaresque adventure novel

definitions.definition: stupidly obstinate.
definitions.example: I was too pig-headed to listen

origin: late Middle English: from Latin pius ‘dutiful, pious’ + -ous.

definitions.definition: devoutly religious.
definitions.example: a deeply pious woman

definitions.definition: (of a hope) sincere but unlikely to be fulfilled.

origin: mid 16th century (denoting animosity between two or more people): from French piquer ‘prick, irritate’.

definitions.definition: a feeling of irritation or resentment resulting from a slight, especially to one's pride.
definitions.example: he left in a fit of pique

definitions.definition: arouse (interest or curiosity).
definitions.example: with his scientific curiosity piqued, he was looking forward to being able to analyse his find

definitions.definition: feel irritated or resentful.
definitions.example: she was piqued by his curtness

definitions.definition: pride oneself.
definitions.example: men, who are thought to pique themselves upon their Wit

origin: mid 17th century: from French pic, from the Old French sense ‘stabbing blow’, of unknown ultimate origin.

definitions.definition: (in piquet) the scoring of 30 points on declarations and play before one's opponent scores anything.
score a pique against (one's opponent).

origin: mid 19th century: from French, literally ‘backstitched’, past participle of piquer .

definitions.definition: stiff fabric, typically cotton, woven in a strongly ribbed or raised pattern.
definitions.example: a white cotton piqué shirt

definitions.definition: (of a fruit or plant) containing much pith.
(of language or style) terse and vigorously expressive.
definitions.example: his characteristically pithy comments

origin: early 19th century: from French, from plat ‘flat’.

definitions.definition: a remark or statement, especially one with a moral content, that has been used too often to be interesting or thoughtful.
definitions.example: he masks his disdain for her with platitudes about how she should believe in herself more

origin: late Middle English: from Old French, from late Latin plenitudo, from plenus ‘full’.

definitions.definition: an abundance.
definitions.example: an ancient Celtic god thought to bring a plenitude of wealth or food

origin: Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French plit ‘fold’. The -gh- spelling is by association with plight2.

definitions.definition: a dangerous, difficult, or otherwise unfortunate situation.
definitions.example: we must direct our efforts towards relieving the plight of children living in poverty

origin: Old English plihtan  ‘endanger’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch plicht and German Pflicht ‘duty’. The current sense is recorded only from Middle English, but is probably original, in view of the related Germanic words.

definitions.definition: pledge or solemnly promise (one's faith or loyalty).
definitions.example: men to plighted vows were faithful

origin: late Middle English: from Old French, literally ‘pricking’, present participle of poindre, from Latin pungere ‘to prick’.

definitions.definition: evoking a keen sense of sadness or regret.
definitions.example: a poignant reminder of the passing of time

definitions.definition: of or involving strongly critical or disputatious writing or speech.
definitions.example: a polemical essay

origin: early 16th century: from French poltron, from Italian poltrone, perhaps from poltro ‘sluggard’.

definitions.definition: an utter coward.
definitions.example: come on, you poltroons!

definitions.definition: of or like a portent; of momentous significance.
definitions.example: this portentous year in Canadian history

origin: late Middle English: from Latin potentatus ‘dominion’, from potent- ‘being able or powerful’ (see potent1).

definitions.definition: a monarch or ruler, especially an autocratic one.

origin: late 15th century (in the sense ‘bar a route or passage’): from Latin praecludere, from prae ‘before’ + claudere ‘to shut’.

definitions.definition: prevent from happening; make impossible.
definitions.example: the secret nature of his work precluded official recognition

origin: mid 17th century: from Latin praecox, praecoc- (from praecoquere ‘ripen fully’, from prae ‘before’ + coquere ‘to cook’) + -ious.

definitions.definition: (of a child) having developed certain abilities or inclinations at an earlier age than is usual or expected.
definitions.example: a precocious, solitary boy

origin: late Middle English: from Latin praeeminent- ‘towering above, excelling’, from the verb praeeminere, from prae ‘before’ + eminere ‘stand out’.

definitions.definition: surpassing all others; very distinguished in some way.
definitions.example: the world's pre-eminent expert on asbestos

origin: late Middle English: from Latin praepotent- ‘having greater power’, from prae ‘before, ahead’ + posse ‘be able’.

definitions.definition: greater than others in power or influence.

origin: early 17th century: from Latin praescient- ‘knowing beforehand’, from the verb praescire, from prae ‘before’ + scire ‘know’.

definitions.definition: having or showing knowledge of events before they take place.
definitions.example: a prescient warning

origin: mid 19th century: from French, from preste ‘nimble’ + Latin digitus ‘finger’ + -ation.

definitions.definition: conjuring tricks performed as entertainment.

origin: Middle English: from Old French presumptueux, from late Latin praesumptuosus, variant of praesumptiosus ‘full of boldness’, from praesumptio (see presumption).

definitions.definition: (of a person or their behaviour) failing to observe the limits of what is permitted or appropriate.
definitions.example: I hope I won't be considered presumptuous if I offer some advice

definitions.definition: beyond what is normal or natural.
definitions.example: autumn had arrived with preternatural speed

origin: early 16th century: from Latin praetextus ‘outward display’, from the verb praetexere ‘to disguise’, from prae ‘before’ + texere ‘weave’.

definitions.definition: a reason given in justification of a course of action that is not the real reason.
definitions.example: the rebels had the perfect pretext for making their move

origin: mid 16th century (earlier (Middle English) as prevarication and prevaricator ), in the sense ‘go astray, transgress’: from Latin praevaricat- ‘walked crookedly, deviated’, from the verb praevaricari, from prae ‘before’ + varicari ‘straddle’.

definitions.definition: speak or act in an evasive way.
definitions.example: he seemed to prevaricate when journalists asked pointed questions

origin: late 17th century (as a verb): probably ultimately from Old French prin, Provençal prim ‘excellent, delicate’, from Latin primus ‘first’.

definitions.definition: feeling or showing disapproval of anything regarded as improper; stiffly correct.
definitions.example: a very prim and proper lady

definitions.definition: purse (the mouth or lips) into a prim expression.
definitions.example: Laurie primmed up his mouth

origin: late Middle English: from Latin probitas, from probus ‘good’.

definitions.definition: the quality of having strong moral principles; honesty and decency.
definitions.example: financial probity

origin: late Middle English: from late Latin prodigalis, from Latin prodigus ‘lavish’.

definitions.definition: spending money or using resources freely and recklessly; wastefully extravagant.
definitions.example: prodigal habits die hard

definitions.definition: having or giving something on a lavish scale.
definitions.example: the dessert was prodigal with whipped cream

definitions.definition: a person who spends money in a recklessly extravagant way.

origin: Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French proffrir, from Latin pro- ‘before’ + offerre ‘to offer’.

definitions.definition: hold out or put forward (something) to someone for acceptance.
definitions.example: she proffered a glass of wine

definitions.definition: an offer or proposal.

origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘overthrown, routed’): from Latin profligatus ‘dissolute’, past participle of profligare ‘overthrow, ruin’, from pro- ‘forward, down’ + fligere ‘strike down’.

definitions.definition: recklessly extravagant or wasteful in the use of resources.
definitions.example: profligate consumers of energy

definitions.definition: licentious; dissolute.
definitions.example: he succumbed to drink and a profligate lifestyle

definitions.definition: a licentious, dissolute person.
definitions.example: he is a drunkard and a profligate

definitions.definition: great depth of insight or knowledge.
definitions.example: the simplicity and profundity of the message

origin: late Middle English: from medieval Latin prognosticat-, from the verb prognosticare ‘make a prediction’ (see prognostic).

definitions.definition: foretell or prophesy (a future event).
definitions.example: the economists were prognosticating financial Armageddon

origin: mid 16th century (earlier (late 15th century) as promulgation ): from Latin promulgat- ‘exposed to public view’, from the verb promulgare, from pro- ‘out, publicly’ + mulgere ‘cause to come forth’ (literally ‘to milk’).

definitions.definition: promote or make widely known (an idea or cause).
definitions.example: these objectives have to be promulgated within the organization

origin: late Middle English: from Old French propinquité, from Latin propinquitas, from propinquus ‘near’, from prope ‘near to’.

definitions.definition: the state of being close to someone or something; proximity.
definitions.example: he kept his distance as though afraid propinquity might lead him into temptation

definitions.definition: close kinship.

origin: late 16th century (as a noun denoting a prose writer): from late Latin prosaicus, from Latin prosa ‘straightforward (discourse)’ (see prose). Current senses of the adjective date from the mid 18th century.

definitions.definition: having or using the style or diction of prose as opposed to poetry; lacking imaginativeness or originality.
definitions.example: prosaic language can't convey the experience

origin: late 18th century: from French, from the verb provenir ‘come or stem from’, from Latin provenire, from pro- ‘forth’ + venire ‘come’.

definitions.definition: the place of origin or earliest known history of something.
definitions.example: an orange rug of Iranian provenance

origin: late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin prudent-, contraction of provident- ‘foreseeing, attending to’ (see provident).

definitions.definition: acting with or showing care and thought for the future.
definitions.example: no prudent money manager would authorize a loan without first knowing its purpose

origin: late 16th century (in the sense ‘having a mental itching’): from Latin prurient- ‘itching, longing’ and ‘being wanton’, from the verb prurire .

definitions.definition: having or encouraging an excessive interest in sexual matters, especially the sexual activity of others.
definitions.example: she'd been the subject of much prurient curiosity

origin: mid 17th century: from Latin pugnax, pugnac- (from pugnare ‘to fight’, from pugnus ‘fist’) + -ious.

definitions.definition: eager or quick to argue, quarrel, or fight.
definitions.example: his public statements became increasingly pugnacious

origin: late Middle English: from Old French purgatif, -ive, from late Latin purgativus, from purgat- ‘purified’, from the verb purgare (see purge).

definitions.definition: strongly laxative in effect.
a laxative.
definitions.example: a widely employed and useful purgative

origin: late Middle English: from Old French putatif, -ive or late Latin putativus, from Latin putat- ‘thought’, from the verb putare .

definitions.definition: generally considered or reputed to be.
definitions.example: the putative author of the book

origin: late 16th century: perhaps partly from Latin quando ‘when’.

definitions.definition: a state of perplexity or uncertainty over what to do in a difficult situation.
definitions.example: Kate was in a quandary

origin: Old English cwellan  ‘kill’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch kwellen and German quälen .

definitions.definition: put an end to (a rebellion or other disorder), typically by the use of force.
definitions.example: extra police were called to quell the disturbance

origin: late 15th century: from late Latin querulosus, from Latin querulus, from queri ‘complain’.

definitions.definition: complaining in a rather petulant or whining manner.
definitions.example: she became querulous and demanding
synonyms: like a bear with a sore head

origin: early 19th century: French, from raconter ‘relate, recount’.

definitions.definition: a person who tells anecdotes in a skilful and amusing way.
definitions.example: a colourful raconteur

definitions.definition: characterized by bitterness or resentment.
definitions.example: sixteen miserable months of rancorous disputes

origin: Middle English: from Old French rancler, from rancle, draoncle ‘festering sore’, from an alteration of medieval Latin dracunculus, diminutive of draco ‘serpent’.

definitions.definition: (of a comment or fact) cause continuing annoyance or resentment.
definitions.example: the casual manner of his dismissal still rankles

definitions.definition: (of a wound or sore) continue to be painful; fester.
definitions.example: the wound is but skinned over and rankles still at the bottom

origin: mid 17th century: from Latin rapax, rapac- (from rapere ‘to snatch’) + -ious.

definitions.definition: aggressively greedy or grasping.
definitions.example: rapacious landlords

origin: French, from rapprocher, from re- (expressing intensive force) + approcher ‘to approach’.

definitions.definition: (especially in international affairs) an establishment or resumption of harmonious relations.
definitions.example: there were signs of a growing rapprochement between the two countries

definitions.definition: (of air, especially that at high altitudes) of lower pressure than usual; thin.
definitions.example: every ounce carried counts triple when you're trudging uphill in rarefied air

definitions.definition: distant from the lives and concerns of ordinary people; esoteric.
definitions.example: rarefied scholarly pursuits

origin: late Middle English: from Old French rarefier, or medieval Latin rareficare, based on Latin rarus ‘rare’ + facere ‘make’.

definitions.definition: make or become less dense or solid.
definitions.example: air rarefies and degrounds the physical body

origin: mid 19th century: from Latin recalcitrant- ‘kicking out with the heels’, from the verb recalcitrare, based on calx, calc- ‘heel’.

definitions.definition: having an obstinately uncooperative attitude towards authority or discipline.
definitions.example: a class of recalcitrant fifteen-year-olds

definitions.definition: a person with an obstinately uncooperative attitude.
definitions.example: a stiff-necked recalcitrant and troublemaker

origin: mid 16th century: from Latin recantare ‘revoke’, from re- (expressing reversal) + cantare ‘sing, chant’.

definitions.definition: say that one no longer holds an opinion or belief, especially one considered heretical.
definitions.example: heretics were burned if they would not recant
