definitions.definition: understood or implied without being stated.
definitions.example: your silence may be taken to mean tacit agreement

origin: late 18th century: from Latin taciturnus, from tacitus (see tacit).

definitions.definition: (of a person) reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little.
definitions.example: after such gatherings she would be taciturn and morose

origin: Middle English tought  ‘distended’, perhaps originally a variant of tough.

definitions.definition: stretched or pulled tight; not slack.
definitions.example: the fabric stays taut without adhesive

origin: early 17th century: short for tawdry lace, a fine silk lace or ribbon worn as a necklace in the 16th–17th centuries, contraction of St Audrey's lace : Audrey was a later form of Etheldrida (died 679), patron saint of Ely where tawdry laces, along with cheap imitations and other cheap finery, were traditionally sold at a fair.

definitions.definition: showy but cheap and of poor quality.
definitions.example: tawdry jewellery

definitions.definition: cheap and gaudy finery.

origin: mid 18th century (denoting the branch of philosophy that deals with ends or final causes): from modern Latin teleologia, from Greek telos ‘end’ + -logia (see -logy).

definitions.definition: the explanation of phenomena in terms of the purpose they serve rather than of the cause by which they arise.
definitions.example: no theory of history can do without teleology

origin: late Middle English: from Latin temeritas, from temere ‘rashly’.

definitions.definition: excessive confidence or boldness; audacity.
definitions.example: no one had the temerity to question his conclusions

origin: late Middle English: from late Latin tempestuosus, from Latin tempestas (see tempest).

definitions.definition: characterized by strong and turbulent or conflicting emotion.
definitions.example: he had a reckless and tempestuous streak

definitions.definition: very stormy.
definitions.example: a tempestuous wind

origin: late 16th century: from French, from tenir ‘to hold’, from Latin tenere .

definitions.definition: able to be maintained or defended against attack or objection.
definitions.example: such a simplistic approach is no longer tenable

definitions.definition: (of an office, position, scholarship, etc.) able to be held or used.
definitions.example: a scholarship of £200 per annum tenable for three years

origin: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin tenebrosus, from tenebrae ‘darkness’.

definitions.definition: dark; shadowy or obscure.
definitions.example: the tenebrous spiral staircase of the self

origin: late Middle English: via Old French from medieval Latin, based on tenere ‘to hold’; so named because the tenor part was allotted (and therefore ‘held’) the melody.

definitions.definition: a singing voice between baritone and alto or countertenor, the highest of the ordinary adult male range.
definitions.example: the Serenade for tenor, horn, and strings

definitions.definition: an instrument, especially a saxophone, trombone, tuba, or viol, of the second or third lowest pitch in its family.
definitions.example: a tenor sax

origin: Middle English: from Old French tenour, from Latin tenor ‘course, substance, import of a law’, from tenere ‘to hold’.

definitions.definition: the general meaning, sense, or content of something.
definitions.example: the general tenor of the debate

definitions.definition: the actual wording of a document.
the time that must elapse before a bill of exchange or promissory note becomes due for payment.

origin: late 16th century: formed irregularly from Latin tenuis ‘thin’ + -ous.

definitions.definition: very weak or slight.
definitions.example: the tenuous link between interest rates and investment

origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘prosperity, acquired wealth, success’): from Old Norse, from thrífa ‘grasp, get hold of’. Compare with thrive.

definitions.definition: the quality of using money and other resources carefully and not wastefully.
definitions.example: the values of thrift and self-reliance

definitions.definition: a European plant which forms low-growing tufts of slender leaves with rounded pink flower heads, growing chiefly on sea cliffs and mountains.

origin: Old English (ge)thrang  ‘crowd, tumult’, of Germanic origin. The early sense of the verb (Middle English) was ‘press violently, force one's way’.

definitions.definition: a large, densely packed crowd of people or animals.
definitions.example: he pushed his way through the throng

definitions.definition: (of a crowd) fill or be present in (a place or area).
definitions.example: a crowd thronged the station

origin: late 15th century: from Latin tingere ‘to dip or colour’. The noun dates from the mid 18th century.

definitions.definition: colour slightly.
definitions.example: a mass of white blossom tinged with pink

definitions.definition: a trace of a colour.
definitions.example: there was a faint pink tinge to the sky

origin: Middle English (in the general sense ‘wrong, injury’): from Old French, from medieval Latin tortum ‘wrong, injustice’, neuter past participle of Latin torquere ‘to twist’.

definitions.definition: a wrongful act or an infringement of a right (other than under contract) leading to legal liability.
definitions.example: public nuisance is a crime as well as a tort

definitions.definition: relating to or characteristic of a traitor; treacherous.
definitions.example: when his traitorous actions were discovered, he was imprisoned

origin: late Middle English (in trammel (sense 2 of the noun)): from Old French tramail, from a medieval Latin variant of trimaculum, perhaps from Latin tri- ‘three’ + macula ‘mesh’.

definitions.definition: restrictions or impediments to freedom of action.
definitions.example: we will forge our own future, free from the trammels of materialism

definitions.definition: a three-layered dragnet, designed so that a fish entering through one of the large-meshed outer sections will push part of the finer-meshed central section through the large meshes on the further side, forming a pocket in which the fish is trapped.
an instrument consisting of a board with two grooves intersecting at right angles, in which the two ends of a beam compass can slide to draw an ellipse.
a hook in a fireplace for a kettle.
deprive of freedom of action.
definitions.example: we have no wish to be trammelled by convention

definitions.definition: (of an element) having a higher atomic number than uranium (92).

origin: Middle English (in treacherous (sense 1 of the adjective)): from Old French trecherous, from trecheor ‘a cheat’, from trechier ‘to cheat’.

definitions.definition: guilty of or involving betrayal or deception.
definitions.example: a treacherous Gestapo agent

definitions.definition: (of ground, water, conditions, etc.) presenting hidden or unpredictable dangers.
definitions.example: a holidaymaker was swept away by treacherous currents

origin: early 17th century: from Latin tremulus (from tremere ‘tremble’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: shaking or quivering slightly.
definitions.example: Barbara's voice was tremulous

origin: Middle English (in trenchant (sense 2)): from Old French, literally ‘cutting’, present participle of trenchier (see trench).

definitions.definition: vigorous or incisive in expression or style.
definitions.example: the White Paper makes trenchant criticisms of health authorities

definitions.definition: (of a weapon or tool) having a sharp edge.
definitions.example: a trenchant blade

definitions.definition: unimportant or trivial.
definitions.example: a trifling sum

origin: Middle English (also denoting an idle story told to deceive or amuse): from Old French trufle, by-form of trufe ‘deceit’, of unknown origin. The verb derives from Old French truffler ‘mock, deceive’.

definitions.definition: treat without seriousness or respect.
definitions.example: he is not a man to be trifled with

definitions.definition: talk or act frivolously.
definitions.example: we will not trifle—life is too short

origin: mid 16th century: from Latin tritus, past participle of terere ‘to rub’.

definitions.definition: (of a remark or idea) lacking originality or freshness; dull on account of overuse.
definitions.example: this point may now seem obvious and trite

origin: mid 16th century: from Latin truculentus, from trux, truc- ‘fierce’.

definitions.definition: eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressively defiant.
definitions.example: the truculent attitude of farmers to cheaper imports

origin: late 15th century: from French, or from Latin turpitudo, from turpis ‘disgraceful, base’.

definitions.definition: depraved or wicked behaviour or character.
definitions.example: acts of moral turpitude

origin: early 17th century: from Latin tutela ‘keeping’, (from tut- ‘watched’, from the verb tueri ) + -age.

definitions.definition: protection of or authority over someone or something; guardianship.

origin: late 18th century: alteration of earlier twattle, of unknown origin.

definitions.definition: trivial or foolish speech or writing; nonsense.
definitions.example: he dismissed the novel as self-indulgent twaddle

definitions.definition: talk or write in a trivial or foolish way.
definitions.example: what is that old fellow twaddling about?

origin: late Middle English: from Latin tiro, medieval Latin tyro ‘recruit’.

definitions.definition: a beginner or novice.

origin: late Middle English (in umbrage (sense 2)): from Old French, from Latin umbra ‘shadow’. An early sense was ‘shadowy outline’, giving rise to ‘ground for suspicion’, whence the current notion of ‘offence’.

definitions.definition: offence or annoyance.
definitions.example: she took umbrage at his remarks

definitions.definition: shade or shadow, especially as cast by trees.

origin: mid 16th century: from un-1 ‘not’ + obsolete conscionable, from conscience (interpreted as a plural) + -able.

definitions.definition: not right or reasonable.
definitions.example: the unconscionable conduct of his son

origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘greasy’): from medieval Latin unctuosus, from Latin unctus ‘anointing’, from unguere ‘anoint’.

definitions.definition: excessively flattering or ingratiating; oily.
definitions.example: he seemed anxious to please but not in an unctuous way

definitions.definition: (chiefly of minerals) having a greasy or soapy feel.
not defiled; pure.

origin: mid 17th century: from late Latin undulatus, from Latin unda ‘a wave’.

definitions.definition: move or go with a smooth up-and-down motion.
definitions.example: the surface of the liquid undulated gently

definitions.definition: (especially of a leaf) having a wavy surface or edge.
tireless; persistent.
definitions.example: his apparently unflagging enthusiasm impressed her

origin: mid 17th century: from un-1 ‘not’ + obsolete gainly ‘graceful’, based on Old Norse gegn ‘straight’.

definitions.definition: (of a person or movement) awkward; clumsy.
definitions.example: an ungainly walk
synonyms: like a bull in a china shop

definitions.definition: (of an action or decision) performed by or affecting only one person, group, or country involved in a situation, without the agreement of another or the others.
definitions.example: unilateral nuclear disarmament

definitions.definition: relating to or affecting only one side of an organ, the body, or another structure.
definitions.example: unilateral cerebral lesions

definitions.definition: having or showing no moral principles; not honest or fair.
definitions.example: unscrupulous landlords might be tempted to harass existing tenants

definitions.definition: (of behaviour or actions) not proper or appropriate.
definitions.example: an unseemly squabble

definitions.definition: not cautious of possible dangers or problems.
definitions.example: accidents can happen to the unwary traveller

origin: late Old English upbrēdan  ‘allege (something) as a basis for censure’, based on braid in the obsolete sense ‘brandish’. The current sense dates from Middle English.

definitions.definition: find fault with (someone); scold.
definitions.example: he was upbraided for his slovenly appearance

origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘urban’): from French urbain or Latin urbanus (see urban).

definitions.definition: (of a person) courteous and refined in manner.
definitions.example: they are charming and urbane

origin: late 16th century (in the sense ‘sway unsteadily’): from Latin vacillat- ‘swayed’, from the verb vacillare .

definitions.definition: waver between different opinions or actions; be indecisive.
definitions.example: I vacillated between teaching and journalism

origin: early 18th century: from Latin valetudinarius ‘in ill health’ (from valetudo ‘health’, from valere ‘be well’) + -an.

definitions.definition: a person who is unduly anxious about their health.
showing undue concern about one's health.
definitions.example: the valetudinarian English

origin: 1920s: back-formation from valorization (from French valorisation, from valeur ‘value’).

definitions.definition: give or ascribe value or validity to.
definitions.example: the culture valorizes the individual

origin: mid 17th century (used originally in description of drinks as ‘lacking in flavour’): from Latin vapidus .

definitions.definition: offering nothing that is stimulating or challenging; bland.
definitions.example: tuneful but vapid musical comedies

origin: late Middle English: via Old French from medieval Latin vassallus ‘retainer’, of Celtic origin; compare with vavasour.

definitions.definition: a holder of land by feudal tenure on conditions of homage and allegiance.

origin: late Middle English (describing pain or temperature, in the sense ‘intense, high in degree’): from French véhément or Latin vehement- ‘impetuous, violent’, perhaps from an unrecorded adjective meaning ‘deprived of mind’, influenced by vehere ‘carry’.

definitions.definition: showing strong feeling; forceful, passionate, or intense.
definitions.example: her voice was low but vehement

origin: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘available for purchase’, referring to merchandise or a favour): from Latin venalis, from venum ‘thing for sale’.

definitions.definition: showing or motivated by susceptibility to bribery; corrupt.
definitions.example: local customs officers are notoriously venal

origin: late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin venerabilis, from the verb venerari (see venerate).

definitions.definition: accorded a great deal of respect, especially because of age, wisdom, or character.
definitions.example: a venerable statesman

origin: Middle English: via Old French from late Latin venialis, from venia ‘forgiveness’.

definitions.definition: denoting a sin that is not regarded as depriving the soul of divine grace.
definitions.example: we cannot prevent ourselves sometimes from dreaming of performing venial if not mortal sins

origin: early 17th century: from Latin verisimilitudo, from verisimilis ‘probable’, from veri (genitive of verus ‘true’) + similis ‘like’.

definitions.definition: the appearance of being true or real.
definitions.example: the detail gives the novel some verisimilitude

origin: early 17th century (in the sense ‘alternation’): from French, or from Latin vicissitudo, from vicissim ‘by turns’, from vic- ‘turn, change’.

definitions.definition: a change of circumstances or fortune, typically one that is unwelcome or unpleasant.
definitions.example: her husband's sharp vicissitudes of fortune

definitions.definition: alternation between opposite or contrasting things.
definitions.example: the vicissitude of the seasons

origin: mid 16th century: probably a shortening of obsolete envy, via Old French from Latin invitare ‘challenge’.

definitions.definition: compete eagerly with someone in order to do or achieve something.
definitions.example: the athletes were vying for a place in the British team

origin: late 15th century (in the sense ‘characteristic of a man’): from French viril or Latin virilis, from vir ‘man’.

definitions.definition: having strength, energy, and a strong sex drive (typically used of a man).
definitions.example: he was a powerful, virile man

origin: mid 16th century: from Latin vitiat- ‘impaired’, from the verb vitiare, from vitium (see vice1).

definitions.definition: spoil or impair the quality or efficiency of.
definitions.example: development programmes have been vitiated by the rise in population

origin: mid 16th century: from Latin vituperat- ‘censured, disparaged’ (see vituperation).

definitions.definition: blame or insult (someone) in strong or violent language.

origin: mid 17th century: from Latin vivax, vivac- ‘lively, vigorous’ (from vivere ‘to live’) + -ious.

definitions.definition: attractively lively and animated (typically used of a woman).
definitions.example: her vivacious and elegant mother
synonyms: full of the joys of spring

definitions.definition: expressing or characterized by vehement opinions; loud and forceful.
definitions.example: he was a vociferous opponent of the takeover

definitions.definition: the quality of talking fluently, readily, or incessantly; talkativeness.
definitions.example: her legendary volubility deserted her

origin: early 17th century: partly from late Latin voluminosus ‘having many coils’, partly from Latin volumen, volumin- (see volume).

definitions.definition: (of clothes) very loose or full; having much fabric.
definitions.example: a voluminous purple cloak

definitions.definition: (of writing) very lengthy and detailed.
definitions.example: we all scribbled down voluminous notes

origin: early 17th century: from Latin volupt(u)arius, from voluptas ‘pleasure’.

definitions.definition: a person devoted to luxury and sensual pleasure.
concerned with or characterized by luxury and sensual pleasure.
definitions.example: a voluptuary decade when high living was in style

origin: Old English walwian  ‘to roll about’, of Germanic origin, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin volvere ‘to roll’.

definitions.definition: (chiefly of large mammals) roll about or lie in mud or water, especially to keep cool or avoid biting insects.
definitions.example: there were watering places where buffalo liked to wallow

definitions.definition: (of a person) indulge in an unrestrained way in (something that one finds pleasurable).
definitions.example: I was wallowing in the luxury of the hotel

definitions.definition: an act of wallowing.
definitions.example: a wallow in nostalgia

definitions.definition: a depression containing mud or shallow water, formed by the wallowing of large mammals.
definitions.example: a buffalo wallow

origin: Old English wann  ‘dark, black’, of unknown origin.

definitions.definition: (of a person's complexion or appearance) pale and giving the impression of illness or exhaustion.
definitions.example: she was looking wan and bleary-eyed

definitions.definition: wide area network.
Nigeria (international vehicle registration).
a computer network in which the computers connected may be far apart, generally having a radius of more than 1 km.

origin: Middle English wantowen  ‘rebellious, lacking discipline’, from wan-  ‘badly’ + Old English togen  ‘trained’ (related to team and tow1).

definitions.definition: (of a cruel or violent action) deliberate and unprovoked.
definitions.example: sheer wanton vandalism

definitions.definition: sexually unrestrained or having many casual sexual relationships (typically used of a woman).
definitions.example: her cheeks burned as she recalled how forward she had been, how wanton

definitions.definition: growing profusely; luxuriant.
definitions.example: where wanton ivy twines

definitions.definition: a sexually unrestrained woman.
definitions.example: she'd behaved like a wanton

definitions.definition: play; frolic.
definitions.example: they sat gazing at the white-flecked pure blue sea and the various gulls that wantoned in the wake

definitions.definition: behave in a sexually unrestrained way.
definitions.example: women who have wantoned with suitors

origin: late Middle English (as a noun in the sense ‘melody’): from Old Northern French werble (noun), werbler (verb), of Germanic origin; related to whirl.

definitions.definition: (of a bird) sing softly and with a succession of constantly changing notes.
definitions.example: larks were warbling in the trees

definitions.definition: a warbling sound or utterance.
definitions.example: through the wall came a faint warble

origin: late Middle English: of uncertain origin.

definitions.definition: a swelling or abscess beneath the skin on the back of cattle, horses, and other mammals, caused by the presence of the larva of a warble fly.

origin: Old English waru  ‘commodities’, of Germanic origin, perhaps the same word as Scots ware ‘cautiousness’, and having the primary sense ‘object of care’; related to ware2.

definitions.definition: pottery, typically that of a specified type.
definitions.example: blue-and-white majolica ware

origin: Old English warian  ‘be on one's guard’, from a Germanic base meaning ‘observe, take care’.

definitions.definition: used as a warning cry, typically during a hunt.

origin: late Middle English: shortening of obsolete awayward  ‘turned away’; compare with froward.

definitions.definition: difficult to control or predict because of wilful or perverse behaviour.
definitions.example: a wayward adolescent

origin: mid 17th century: perhaps from German wedeln ‘cringe, fawn’, from Wedel ‘tail, fan’.

definitions.definition: use flattery or coaxing in order to persuade someone to do something or give one something.
definitions.example: she wheedled her way on to the guest list

origin: Old English hwettan, of Germanic origin; related to German wetzen, based on an adjective meaning ‘sharp’.

definitions.definition: sharpen the blade of (a tool or weapon).
definitions.example: she took out her dagger and began to whet its blade in even, rhythmic strokes

definitions.definition: a thing that stimulates appetite or desire.
definitions.example: he swallowed his two dozen oysters as a whet

definitions.definition: cut with a whipsaw.
definitions.example: he was whipsawing lumber

definitions.definition: subject to two difficult situations or opposing pressures at the same time.
definitions.example: the army has been whipsawed by a shrinking budget and a growing pool of recruits

definitions.definition: skilled at gaining an advantage, especially deceitfully.
definitions.example: his wily opponents

origin: Middle English (originally in the sense ‘kick restlessly from pain or impatience’): from an Anglo-Norman French variant of Old French guenchir ‘turn aside’.

definitions.definition: make a slight involuntary grimace or shrinking movement of the body out of pain or distress.
definitions.example: he winced at the disgust in her voice

definitions.definition: an instance of wincing.

origin: late 17th century (in the sense ‘winch’): variant of winch.

definitions.definition: a roller for moving textile fabric through a dyeing vat.

origin: Old English wīthig, of Germanic origin; related to German Weide .

definitions.definition: a tough, flexible branch of an osier or other willow, used for tying, binding, or basketry.
definitions.example: it is fixed with withies tied to the common rafters

origin: Old English wrǣstan  ‘twist, tighten’, of Germanic origin; related to Danish vriste, also to wrist.

definitions.definition: forcibly pull (something) from a person's grasp.
definitions.example: Leila tried to wrest her arm from his hold

definitions.definition: distort the meaning or interpretation of (something) to suit one's own interests or views.
definitions.example: you appear convinced of my guilt, and wrest every reply I have made

definitions.definition: a key for tuning a harp or piano.

origin: Old English, as a general term denoting written matter, from the Germanic base of write.

definitions.definition: a form of written command in the name of a court or other legal authority to act, or abstain from acting, in a particular way.
definitions.example: the two reinstated officers issued a writ for libel against the applicants

definitions.definition: a piece or body of writing.
archaic past participle of write.

origin: early 16th century (in the sense ‘contorted’): from Old English wrīgian ‘tend, incline’, in Middle English ‘deviate, swerve, contort’.

definitions.definition: using or expressing dry, especially mocking, humour.
definitions.example: a wry smile

definitions.definition: (of a person's face or features) twisted into an expression of disgust, disappointment, or annoyance.
(of the neck or features) distorted or turned to one side.
definitions.example: a remedy for wry necks

origin: late 16th century: from French zani or Italian zan(n)i, Venetian form of Gianni, Giovanni ‘John’, stock name of the servants acting as clowns in the commedia dell'arte.

definitions.definition: amusingly unconventional and idiosyncratic.
definitions.example: his zany humour

definitions.definition: a zany person.

origin: late Middle English: from Old French or medieval Latin cenit, based on Arabic samt (ar-ra's) ‘path (over the head)’.

definitions.definition: the time at which something is most powerful or successful.
definitions.example: in 1977, punk was at its zenith

definitions.definition: the point in the sky or celestial sphere directly above an observer.
